Title: Al techniques: A comprehensive catalogue
Source title: IEEE Intelligent Systems and Their Applications
Affiliations: Intelligent Systems Laboratory, Michigan State University, United States
Authors with affiliations: Sticklen, J., Intelligent Systems Laboratory, Michigan State University, United States
Abstract: This issue, we are going to do something a bit unorthodox. Most books we review are aimed at AI practitioners or research scholars - both of whom are pushing at frontiers, although usually in different ways. This time, we've chosen a short reference work intended for AI novices: Artifical Intelligence Techniques: A Comprehensive Catalogue, 4th ed., edited by Alan Bundy (135 pp., $29.00, Springer-Verlag, Berlin, 1996, ISBN 3-540-59323-3). The book's basic idea is to have a number of AI professionals develop short abstracts of AI techniques, along with supporting terminology, and to present these abstracts at a level accessible by someone either new to AI or in a different branch of AI. This goal is laudable. One of the more distressing, but inevitable (it seems), trends in AI is a fragmentation of the field into many subfields. A work such as that targeted by Bundy would help ease the fragmentation by at least giving us a common meeting place. Because this book is aimed partly at readers new to AI, we've selected two graduate students - Fran Bakowska, an MSc student and research assistant, and Robert Hawkins, a PhD student and graduate research assistant - to give short reviews. They are both from the Intelligent Systems Lab, which I direct. We decided to leave both reviewers to their own devices and asked them not to discuss the reviews with each other until they had submitted their reviews. Most often, reviewers for Intelligent Systems are well-established researchers in their own subareas of AI, who are reviewing the writings of other researchers in the same area; that model would not have worked well for this book. Both reviewers reach similar positions, as you'll see. Perhaps, as AI continues to build on successes, the creation of subfields will accelerate. If so, the AI community - or perhaps better said, the AI confederation - will need a resource such as AI Techniques aspires to be. Maybe such a resource could best be found in some Web-available form. Whatever form it takes, such a resource will no doubt help us, and novices in our area, understand each other, at least at an elementary level.
References: Turing, A.M., Computing Machinery and Intelligence (1950) Mind, 59, pp. 433-460. , Oct; Hodges, A., (1983) Alan Turing: the Enigma, , Random House, London

Authors: Geng L., Chan C., Chen Z., Huang G.
Title: Knowledge engineering of an intelligent system for selection of remediation methods at petroleum contaminated sites
Source title: Technical Meeting / Petroleum Conference of the South Saskatchewan Section 1999
Affiliations: University of Regina, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Geng, L., University of Regina, Canada; Chan, C., University of Regina, Canada; Chen, Z., University of Regina, Canada; Huang, G., University of Regina, Canada
Abstract: Groundwater and soil contamination resulted from light nonaqueous phase liquids (LNAPLs) spills and leakage in petroleum industry is currently one of the major environmental concerns in the North America. Numerous site remediation technologies, generally calssified as ex-situ and in-situ remediation techniques, have been developed and implemented to clean up the contaminated sites in the last two decades. One of the problems associated with ex-situ remediation is the cost of operation. In recent years, in-situ techniques have acquired popularity. However, the selection process of the desired techniques needs a large amount of knowledge. Insufficient expertise in the process may result in large inflation of expenses. In this study, petroleum waste management experts and Artifical Intelligence (AI) researchers worked together to develop an expert system (ES) for the management of petroleum contaminated sites. Various AI techniques were used to construct a tool for site remediaiton decision-making. This paper presents the knowledge engineering processes of knowledge acquisition, conceptual design, and system implementation in the project. The case studies have indicated that the expert system can generate cost-effective remediation alternatives to assist decision-makers. © 1999 CURRAN-CONFERENCE. All rights reserved.

Authors: Lamadé W., Glombitza G., Demiris A.M., Cardenas C., Meinzer H.P., Richter G., Lehnert Th., Herfarth Ch.
Title: Virtual operation planning in liver surgery [Virtuelle Operationsplanung in der Leberchirurgie]
Affiliations: Chirurgische Klinik und Poliklinik, Universität Heidelberg, Germany; Deutsches Krebsforschungszentrum, Heidelberg, Germany; Abteilung Radiodiagnostik, Radiologische Klinik, Universität Heidelberg, Germany; Chir. Klin. und Poliklin. der Univ., Kirschnerstraße 1 (INF 110), D-69120 Heidelberg, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Lamadé, W., Chirurgische Klinik und Poliklinik, Universität Heidelberg, Germany, Chir. Klin. und Poliklin. der Univ., Kirschnerstraße 1 (INF 110), D-69120 Heidelberg, Germany; Glombitza, G., Deutsches Krebsforschungszentrum, Heidelberg, Germany; Demiris, A.M., Deutsches Krebsforschungszentrum, Heidelberg, Germany; Cardenas, C., Deutsches Krebsforschungszentrum, Heidelberg, Germany; Meinzer, H.P., Deutsches Krebsforschungszentrum, Heidelberg, Germany; Richter, G., Abteilung Radiodiagnostik, Radiologische Klinik, Universität Heidelberg, Germany; Lehnert, Th., Chirurgische Klinik und Poliklinik, Universität Heidelberg, Germany; Herfarth, Ch., Chirurgische Klinik und Poliklinik, Universität Heidelberg, Germany
Abstract: The operability of a liver tumour depends on its three-dimensional relation to the intrahepatic vascular trees which define autonomously functioning liver (sub-)segments. The aim of our study was to establish a computer-based three-dimensional volumetric operation planning system for the liver. Methods: Using data from routine helical CT scans the three tissue subclasses of liver parenchyma, liver vessels and liver tumour were segmented semiautomatically. A dedicated segmenting tool was established using region growing algorithms in combination with an "intelligent" border finder. Visualisation is performed by the "Heidelberg Raytracer". The vascular trees are visualised as 3D graphs. Pseudoconnections between portal and hepatic venous trees are separated automatically. Security margins are calculated and the system presents a virtual resection proposal. Results: The 3D anatomy of the liver can be visualised in high quality resulting in good depth perception. Security margins are demonstrated. Dependent liver parenchyma can be recognised automatically on the basis of the vascular trees. The system offers a individualised resection proposal including the tumour, security margin and dependent liver parenchyma. Conclusion: Three-dimensional presentation of the individual liver anatomy of a given patient facilitates the perception of the pathology. Virtual reality combined with artifical intelligence allows calculation of complete resection protocols, which can be quantified and modified interactively. This will make operation planning more objective; patient selection may be improved, and in cases of difficult tumour localisation different resection strategies may be tested. Thus virtual reality in liver surgery will improve teaching, surgical training and planning. It may lead to improved surgical care.
Author Keywords: Liver; Liver resection; Operation planning; Visualisation

Authors: Grigsby J., Kramer R.E., Schneiders J.L., Gates J.R., Smith W.B.
Title: Predicting outcome of anterior temporal lobectomy using simulated neural networks
Affiliations: University of Colorado, Health Science Center, Denver, CO, United States; Colorado Neurological Institute, Epilepsy Center, Englewood, CO, United States; Minnesota Epilepsy Group, St. Paul, MN, United States; Oregon Compreh. Epilepsy Program, Portland, OR, United States; University of Colorado, Health Science Center, 1355 South Colorado Boulevard, Denver, CO 80222, United States
Authors with affiliations: Grigsby, J., University of Colorado, Health Science Center, Denver, CO, United States, Colorado Neurological Institute, Epilepsy Center, Englewood, CO, United States, University of Colorado, Health Science Center, 1355 South Colorado Boulevard, Denver, CO 80222, United States; Kramer, R.E., Colorado Neurological Institute, Epilepsy Center, Englewood, CO, United States; Schneiders, J.L., University of Colorado, Health Science Center, Denver, CO, United States, Colorado Neurological Institute, Epilepsy Center, Englewood, CO, United States; Gates, J.R., Minnesota Epilepsy Group, St. Paul, MN, United States; Smith, W.B., Oregon Compreh. Epilepsy Program, Portland, OR, United States
Abstract: Purpose: Anterior temporal lobectomy (ATL) is an important option for treatment of medically refractory seizures. Patient selection is not always clear-cut, and there is inherent morbidity and mortality associated with the invasive and expensive surgical protocols. To determine whether patient selection might be facilitated by application of artifical intelligence, we developed a model that predicted seizure outcome after ATL, using a simulated neural network (SNN). Methods: Predictions of the model were compared with predictions derived from conventional discriminant function analysis. Neural networks and discriminant functions were devised that would predict the occurrence of both Class 1 outcomes (totally seizure-free), and Class 1 or Class 2 outcomes (nearly or totally seizure-free), using data from 87 patients from three surgical centers. The SNNs and discriminant functions were developed using data from a randomly selected subsample of 65 patients, and both models were cross-validated, using the remaining 22 patients. Results: The discriminant functions showed overall predictive accuracy of 78.5% and 72.7%, while the neural networks demonstrated overall accuracy of 81.8% and 95.4%. Conclusions: Simulated neural networks show promise as adjuncts to decision-making in the selection of epilepsy surgery patients.
Author Keywords: Epilepsy; Neural networks; Outcome prediction; Surgery

Abstract: The article gives the outlines of all principles used in computing included the non-electrical and analog computers and the artifical intelligence followed by citing examples as well. Title: Case-based reasoning and statistics for discovering and forecasting of epidemics

Abstract: We describe the methodology of an early warning system which fulfills the following tasks. (1) discovering of health risks, (2) forecasting of the temporal and spatial spread of epidemics and (3) estimating of consequences of an epidemic w.r.t, the personnel load and costs of the public health service. For mastering this three tasks methods from artifical intelligence and statistics are applied. © Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg 1997.

Abstract: Proposes a self-optimizing intelligent control plan. The description of the model was combined with analytic model and rule model. The optimal analytic control method, the qualitative knowledge of the classical control theory and the expert experience were in-corporated forming the control strategy. So the control rules and the parameter self-regulation rules were better. The performance of the controller approached the optimal control with better robustness and adaptability. This is also confirmed by the result of simulation.

Title: Artificial neural networks applications in cotton spinning processing
Source title: Beltwide cotton conferences. Proc. conf. Nashville, 1996, Vol. 2
Affiliations: Univ of Minho Portugal, Portugal
Authors with affiliations: Cabeco-Silva, M.E., Univ of Minho Portugal, Portugal; Cabeco-Silva, A.A., Univ of Minho Portugal, Portugal; Samarao, J.L., Univ of Minho Portugal, Portugal; Nasrallah, B.N., Univ of Minho Portugal, Portugal
Abstract: With the spread use of HVU/HVT systems in spinning (in the fibers and yarns quality field and the arrival of artifical intelligence, patterns of binary data may be analyzed to detect deviations from patterns produced under statistical control and making recommendations concerning the root cause of the problem and the appropriate corrective action. Expert systems are suitable for understanding aggregate data, comparing what is seen today with patterns from historical databases, can select from several procedures those currently appropriate and determine when the parameters of the model describing the data or model being used for predictive purposes should be changed. In this paper the application of artificial neural networks for the blending of cotton fibers is presented.
Index Keywords: expert systems; neural networks; quality control; spinning, cotton

Title: Application of the technique of virtual reality in a system of control for helicopter
Source title: Beijing Ligong Daxue Xuebao/Transaction of Beijing Institute of Technology
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Beijing Institute of Technology, Beijing 100081, China
Authors with affiliations: Zhan, S., Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Beijing Institute of Technology, Beijing 100081, China; Li, X., Department of Computer Science and Engineering, Beijing Institute of Technology, Beijing 100081, China
Abstract: With increased carrying capacity and fighting capability of armed helicopters, the driver cabin of the armed helicopter is being transformed from double driver cabin to single dirver cabin. While, the pilot's fuction is not only to drive the helicopter, but also to perform navigation, weapons operation, communication and so on. This article briefly discusses the role of the virtual man-machine interface in the control system of the armed helicopter (single driver cabin), and explores the critical technique of virtual reality man-machine interface (including the AI technique, direct display, speech input/output and man-machine engineering).

Title: Reasoning about colour in prolog
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Dept. of Computing Mathematics, University of Wales, Cardiff, United Kingdom; School of Electronic Engineering, Dublin City University, Dublin 9, Ireland
Authors with affiliations: Batchelor, B.G., Dept. of Computing Mathematics, University of Wales, Cardiff, United Kingdom; Whelan, P.F., School of Electronic Engineering, Dublin City University, Dublin 9, Ireland
Abstract: The use of colour as a basis for segmenting images is attractive for a wide variety of industrial inspection applications, especially in the manufacturing of domestic goods, food, pharmaceuticals, toiletries and electronics. Human beings define colours, not formulae, or computer programs. Moreover, no two people have an identical view of what a colour set, such as "canary yellow" is. The article argues that teaching by showing is more relevent than the accepted methods of Colour Science, in the design of factory-floor vision systems. Fast hardware for colour recognition has been available for several years but has not yet received universal acceptance. This article explains how this equipment can be used in conjunction with symbolic processing software, based on the Artifical Intelligence language Prolog. Using this hardware-software system, a programmer is able to express ideas about colours in a natural way. The concepts of colour set union, intersection, generalisation and interpolation are all discussed. © 1994 SPIE. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Automated Visual Inspection; Prolog; Real-time Colour Recognition; Symbolic Programming
Index Keywords: Color; Computer hardware; Computer vision; Artifical intelligence; Automated visual inspection; Hardware-software systems; Industrial inspections; Prolog; Real time; Symbolic processing; Symbolic programming; PROLOG (programming language)

Title: Probabilistic reasoning in an augmented fact-proposition space and its applications
Authors with affiliations: Zhu, Q.
Abstract: A simple and versatile probabilistic reasoning scheme is presented. Based on an augmentation of a multi-dimensional inference space indexed by a Cartesian product of the fact and proposition sets, the scheme simplifies the processes involved in the representation and computation of a probabilistic reasoning system. In the augmented space, a set of auxiliary fields is utilized in addition to the fact-proposition relations to manipulate the uncertainty and incompleteness of the information presented. The scheme enhances the functionality of a probabilistic reasoning and facilitates the building of practical reasoning systems. The utilization of the augmented space in reasoning is illustrated by two problems in computer-vision applications. © 1994.
Author Keywords: artifical intelligence; computer vision; fast-proposition space; Probabilistic reasoning
Index Keywords: Computer vision; Data handling; Inference engines; Probabilistic logics; Augmented fact proposition space; Probabilistic reasoning; Artificial intelligence

Authors: Tomita S., Qin J., O'shima E.
Title: On Modeling for Understanding the Functions Inhering in a Chemical Plant
Affiliations: Dept. of Information Eng., Miyazaki Univ., Miyazaki 889-21, Japan; Japan IBM Systems Engineering Co., Ltd., Chiba 261, Japan; Tokyo Institute of Technology, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Tomita, S., Dept. of Information Eng., Miyazaki Univ., Miyazaki 889-21, Japan; Qin, J., Japan IBM Systems Engineering Co., Ltd., Chiba 261, Japan; O'shima, E., Tokyo Institute of Technology, Japan
Abstract: To develop an intelligent computer-based system for aiding the design of a chemical plant or for operating it, it is indispensable to give the system an ability for understanding the meaning of each function inhering in the plant. In this paper, a model for representing each function is proposed. A function is defined as the ability to realize the particular situation in the plant. They are roughly classified into two categories: ‘processing functions’ for representing the ability to preserve the relation between input and output states and ‘preserving functions’ for representing the ability to preserve the particular state at specific locations inside the plant. The semantics of functions can be made clear by introducing attributes into the model which must be taken into account for recognizing the function. © 1993, The Society of Chemical Engineers, Japan. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Artifical Intelligence; Chemical Process Understanding; Functional Model; Knowledge Verification; Object Oriented Approach
Index Keywords: Chemicals; Computer operating systems; Semantics; Artifical intelligence; Chemical process; Computer-based system; Functional model; Input and outputs; Object oriented approach; Specific location; Chemical plants

Authors: Qin J., Tomita S., O'shima E.
Title: Extraction of the Functional Structure Inhering in a Chemical Plant by Means of the Functional Model
Affiliations: Japan IBM Systems Engineering Co., Ltd., Chiba 261, Japan; Dept. of Information Eng., Miyazaki Univ., Miyazaki 889-21, Japan; Tokyo Institute of Technology, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Qin, J., Japan IBM Systems Engineering Co., Ltd., Chiba 261, Japan; Tomita, S., Dept. of Information Eng., Miyazaki Univ., Miyazaki 889-21, Japan; O'shima, E., Tokyo Institute of Technology, Japan
Abstract: To develop an intelligent system for aiding the operation of a chemical plant, it is indispensable to make the computer understand the meaning of functional structure inhering in the plant. In this paper, a methodology was developed by which all of the functions can be extracted by means of the function model proposed in another paper, when the PFD of a chemical plant and the material states of it are given. The hierarchical relation among the functions and an explanatory structure of it can be generated also. The outline of the methodology is as follows. First, by means of key-units, all of the main functions inhering in the plant can be extracted. Second, by using the knowledge of dependency among functions, the hierarchical relation of the plant's function can be generated. Here, the knowledge of structural conditions that a lowest-level-function has to satisfy and the semantics of each function are given in the form of data structure. By using this knowledge the explanatory structure of the hierarchical relation can be generated. © 1993, The Society of Chemical Engineers, Japan. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Artifical Intelligence; Functional Recognition; Object Oriented Approach; Process Understanding; Semantic Model
Index Keywords: Chemicals; Intelligent systems; Semantics; Artifical intelligence; Functional recognition; Object oriented approach; Process understanding; Semantic Model; Chemical plants

Title: A model for optimum route finding with a raster approach
Source title: Looking to the future with an eye on the past. ACSM/ASPRS convention, New Orleans, 1993. Vol. 3
Affiliations: Dept. of Geography, Univ. of Hawaii at Manoa, 2424 Maile Way, Porteus Hall 445, Honolulu, Hawaii 96822, USA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Tao Fang, Dept. of Geography, Univ. of Hawaii at Manoa, 2424 Maile Way, Porteus Hall 445, Honolulu, Hawaii 96822, USA, United States
Abstract: Optimum route finding is an important topic in Geographic Information Systems (GIS) and Artificial Intelligence (AI). The optimum route finding usually requires a solution to satisfy some criteria and is conventionally solved by a vector approach. This paper explores a new model to solve the problem with a raster approach using the concepts of friction surface, cost surface and least cost pathway finding. A Geographic Information System for automatically finding the least-time-cost route to a hospital from an location of emergency in Oahu Island is designed and accomplished with raster based software IDRISI 4.0. The advantages and limitations of the raster approach are discussed in detail. -Author
Index Keywords: artifical intelligence; GIS; raster; route finder; Hawaii; Oahu Island; USA

Authors: Anantaram C., Joshi Prasad, Deshpande Kiran, Trivedi Piyush
Title: Crew rostering system an expert system for scheduling crew for Indian Airlines
Source title: Proceedings of the Conference on Artificial Intelligence Applications
Affiliations: Tata Consultancy Services, Pune, India
Authors with affiliations: Anantaram, C., Tata Consultancy Services, Pune, India; Joshi, Prasad, Tata Consultancy Services, Pune, India; Deshpande, Kiran, Tata Consultancy Services, Pune, India; Trivedi, Piyush, Tata Consultancy Services, Pune, India
Abstract: Crew rostering involves assignment of crew to a set of flights to meet the operational requirements of an Airline. This assignment has to be done without violating the constraints set for such operations. With a large number of crew, parameters, constraints and objectives involved, the problem domain becomes complex to be handled manually. Automation of such decision-making helps in effective response to dynamic situations and results in better crew-utilization. Conventional programming techniques do not perform well to solve such problems. This paper describes an Expert System developed and deployed for Indian Airlines. An innovative scheduling strategy designed by us has been used as the model. The paper describes this model which is generic for this class of scheduling problems. The development methodology adopted for the system is also presented together with the lessons learnt.
Index Keywords: Air transportation; Database systems; Geographical regions; Knowledge based systems; Personnel; Scheduling; Artifical intelligence applications; Crew scheduling; Expert system development; Expert systems

Authors: Zhang Wen-Ran, Wang Wenhua, Guercio Angela
Title: Open system protocol for agent-oriented programming
Source title: Proceedings of the 4th International Conference on Software Engineering and Knowledge Engineering
Affiliations: Lamar Univ, Beaumont, United States
Authors with affiliations: Zhang, Wen-Ran, Lamar Univ, Beaumont, United States; Wang, Wenhua, Lamar Univ, Beaumont, United States; Guercio, Angela, Lamar Univ, Beaumont, United States
Abstract: The concepts of virtual agents (VAs) and virtual communities (VCs) are proposed for interagent communication and cooperation based on Hewitt's `scientific community' metaphor. VAs are `images' of autonomous agents (expert decision support systems and human decision makers) dynamically created in a local agent's `mind' (or knowledge base) and linked to the remote host through attached network routines. This feature enables VAs to be defined as network domain objects which conceal the details of computer communications and provide an agent-oriented environment for perspective sharing and coordination. Using this protocol VAs can be organized into virtual communities and different social protocols may be modeled as virtual sessions in a virtual conference setting. A prototype system is developed in C and C++ using UDP/IP protocol. The basic ideas are illustrated with an application example. The major advantage of this approach lies in its utility for coordination without coercion.
Index Keywords: Adaptive systems; Artificial intelligence; C (programming language); Computer applications; Computer networks; Data communication systems; Decision support systems; Expert systems; Information science; Man machine systems; Network protocols; Computer supported cooperative work (CSCW); Distributed artifical intelligence (DAI); Multiagent systems (MAS); Scientific community metaphor; UDP/IP protocol; Virtual agents (VA); Virtual communities (VC); Object oriented programming

Title: The Logic and Solving of Partial Order Scalograi Analysis
Affiliations: University of Osaka Prefecture, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Sawada, Z., University of Osaka Prefecture, Japan
Abstract: Partial order scalogram analysis (POSA) is a mu 11i-dimensional scalogram analysis which develops the ideas of the Guttman's one-dimensional scale and enables us to describe the profile of the structure of observed data. However, trying POSA, we find that the systematic method to select variables is almost unknown yet. In this paper, we propose to use the logic programming of Prolog. Prolog is a computer language mainly used in the areas of artifical intelligence studies. When we express the principles and the restrictions of POSA in Prolog, the Prolog language processor searches the solutions of the POSA almost automatically. This method is more faithful to the logic of POSA and more speedy than the quantification method of third type which Hayashi proposed to use for POSA. The computer program of POSA is presented in the last of this paper. © 1992, Japanese Association For Mathematical Sociology. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Logic programming; Partial order scalogram analysis; Prolog

Title: The artifical intelligence applications to learning programme
Affiliations: Communication and Information Research Group, Sheffield City Polytechnic, 36 Collegiate Crescent, Sheffield, S10 2BP England, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Williams, N., Communication and Information Research Group, Sheffield City Polytechnic, 36 Collegiate Crescent, Sheffield, S10 2BP England, United Kingdom
Abstract: The Artificial Intelligence Applications to Learning Programme has been funded since 1987 by what is now known as the Training, Enterprise and Education Directorate (TEED). The Programme aimed to explore and accelerate the use of AI technologies in learning, in both the educational and industrial sectors. The ten demonstrator projects were evaluated for their impact on industry and on further and higher education, while the project was in progress and later during its dissemination phase. The most useful outcomes of evaluation emerged during the latter phase, when the innovations had had an opportunity to become established and brought to market. There were issues related to technology-drive and the need to find problems for which the solution existed through group collaboration. One profitable line of development was to use AI to enrich training systems. An ideal training system must feel "good" to the client, should go beyond existing adaptive training systems, offer a high rate of training, be cost effective, have visual appeal, give sophisticated feedback, should fit closely with the user's current practice, and should have a shele life of more than 3 years. © 1992.
References: Williams, (1989) The Training Agency Conference for Contractors on the Artificial Intelligence Applications to Learning Programme, , Learning Technology Unit, TEED, Moorfoot, Sheffield; Goodman, Evaluation of the Further and Higher Education (FHE) Section of the Training Agency's “AI Applications to Learning Programme” (1989) Innovations in Education & Training International, 26, pp. 322-334

Title: Application of artificial intelligence to pharmacy and medicine
Affiliations: Ohio State University, College of Pharmacy, 500 West 12th Avenue, Columbus, OH 43210, United States
Authors with affiliations: Dasta, J.F., Ohio State University, College of Pharmacy, 500 West 12th Avenue, Columbus, OH 43210, United States
Abstract: Artifical intelligence (AI) is a branch of computer science dealing with solving problems using symbolic programming. It has evolved into a problem solving science with applications in business, engineering, and health care. One application of AI is expert system development. An expert system consists of a knowledge base and inference engine, coupled with a user interface. A crucial aspect of expert system development is knowledge acquisition and implementing computable ways to solve problems. There have been several expert systems developed in medicine to assist physicians with medical diagnosis. Recently, several programs focusing on drug therapy have been described. They provide guidance on drug interactions, drug therapy monitoring, and drug formulary selection. There are many aspects of pharmacy that AI can have an impact on and the reader is challenged to consider these possibilities because they may some day become a reality in pharmacy.

Title: Pattern-directed invocation with changing equations
Affiliations: Artificial Intelligence Laboratory, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, 545 Technology Sq., Cambridge, 02139, MA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Feldman, Y.A., Artificial Intelligence Laboratory, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, 545 Technology Sq., Cambridge, 02139, MA, United States; Rich, C., Artificial Intelligence Laboratory, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, 545 Technology Sq., Cambridge, 02139, MA, United States
Abstract: Pattern-directed invocation is a commonly used artifical-intelligence reasoning technique in which a procedure, called a demon, is automatically invoked whenever a term matching its pattern appears in a ground data base. For completeness, if the data base includes equations, a demon needs to be invoked not only when a term in the data base exactly matches its pattern, but also when some variant of a term in the data base matches. An incremental algorithm has been developed for invoking demons in this situation without generating all possible variants of terms in the data base. The algorithm is shown to be complete for a class of demons, called transparent demons, that obey a natural restriction between the pattern and the body of the demon. Completeness is maintained when new demons, terms, or equations are added to the data base in any order. Equations can also be retracted via a truth maintenance system. The algorithm has been implemented as part of a reasoning system called bread. © 1991 Kluwer Academic Publishers.
Author Keywords: Automated deduction; pattern-directed invocation; truth-maintenance systems

Title: Data/Knowledge Packets as a Means of Supporting Semantic Heterogeneity in Multidatabase Systems
Affiliations: Department of Information and Software Systems Engineering, School of Information Technology and Engineering, George Mason University, Fairfax, VA 22030, United States
Authors with affiliations: Weishar, D., Department of Information and Software Systems Engineering, School of Information Technology and Engineering, George Mason University, Fairfax, VA 22030, United States; Kerschberg, L., Department of Information and Software Systems Engineering, School of Information Technology and Engineering, George Mason University, Fairfax, VA 22030, United States
Abstract: Semantic heterogeneiry in heterogeneous autonomous databases poses problems in instance matches, units conversion 1991, contextual and structural mismatches, etc. In this work we examine some of the research issues in semantic heterogeniety and propose a novel architecture for resolving such problems. The approach involves the use of Artifical Intelligence tools and techniques to construct “domain models,” that is data and knowledge representations of the constituent databases and an overall domain model of the semantic interactions among the databases. These domain models are represented as knowledge sources (KSs) in a blackboard architecture. This architecture lends itself to an opportunistic approach to query processing and goal-directed problem solving. We introduce the notion of Data/Knowledge Packets as a means of supporting both operational and structural semantic heterogeneity. © 1991, ACM. All rights reserved.

Title: Expert systems for cartographic design and production
Authors with affiliations: Forrest, D.
Abstract: There has been considerable interest shown in the application of artificial intelligence and expert systems to cartography. Most are theoretical considerations of what can be done, or what can't, and while a few do report actual working examples, these are all of fairly limited scope or sophistication. A small number of publications try to deal with the general problem of map design, or significant portions of it, but more are concerned with specific aspects of map design and production, such as line simplification, name placement, or symbol selection. -from Author

Authors: Fukuda Toshio, Shibata Takanori, Arai Fumihito, Mitsuoka Toyokazu, Tokita Masatoshi
Title: Adaptation and learning for hierarchical intelligent control
Authors with affiliations: Fukuda, Toshio; Shibata, Takanori; Arai, Fumihito; Mitsuoka, Toyokazu; Tokita, Masatoshi
Abstract: The authors discuss a novel strategy for hierarchical intelligent control. They propose this strategy for a neural-network-based controller to be generalized with the higher level control based on AI (artificial intelligence) and to acquire knowledge heuristically. This system comprises two levels: a learning level and an adaptation level. The neural networks are used for both levels. The learning level has a hierarchical structure for recognition and planning, and is used for the strategy of robotic manipulation in conjunction with the knowledge base in order to expand the adaptive range. The recent information from the adaptation level updates the learning level through a long-term learning process. On the other hand, the adaptation is used for the adjustment of the control law to the current status of the dynamic process.
Index Keywords: Artifical Intelligence - Applications; Neural Networks - Applications; Robots - Learning; Robots - Manipulators; Artificial Neural Networks; Heuristic Knowledge; Intelligent Control; Machine Learning; Neural Controller; Robots

Title: Expert systems in cartographic design
Affiliations: National Center for Geographic Information and Analysis, Department of Geography, State University of New York at Buffalo, Buffalo, NY 14260, USA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Buttenfield, B.P., National Center for Geographic Information and Analysis, Department of Geography, State University of New York at Buffalo, Buffalo, NY 14260, USA, United States; Mark, D.M., National Center for Geographic Information and Analysis, Department of Geography, State University of New York at Buffalo, Buffalo, NY 14260, USA, United States
Abstract: This chapter emphasizes application of expert systems for reference and locational maps. The broader question of expert systems for the design of more abstract maps, such as statistical maps, has seldom been addressed in the literature. It seems clear that an expert system for design of reference maps, locational maps, and some navigation aids may be more feasible in the short term than a system to generate locational maps as well as purely thematic and analytical graphics. In part this is because the symbology of locational maps is more standardized and thus design constraints may be more readily identified. The specificity of map purpose for locational maps also places finite bounds on the range of appropriate symbology, without limiting map projection, scale, use of color, and level of generalization. The purpose of this chapter is to present design criteria for a cartographic expert system that focuses on the problems of map execution, including compilation and production of base features and thematic overlays of locational information. Expert systems and artifical intelligence for other cartographic processes, such as digital scanning, or knowledge-based geographic information systems will not be considered. The discussion remains on a conceptual level. The components of a system and the required functionalities are identified, and the relationships between the two discussed. Progress to date on each phase of the cartographic process will be assessed through a review of the literature. First an overview of expert systems design is given. -from Authors
Index Keywords: cartographic design; design; locational map; statistical map

Title: An expert system for the design and selection of ball bearing parameters
Authors with affiliations: Pathak, M.A.
Abstract: Artificial Intelligence (AI) is an emerging technology. Research in AI is focused on developing computational approaches to intelligent behaviour. The computer programs with which AI could be associated are primarily symbolic processes associated with complexity, ambiguity, indecisiveness, and uncertainty. One of these computer programs is referred to as Knowledge-Based Expert System (KBES) as it represents knowledge acquired from various experts in a particular field of interest to the user. The expert system emulates human behaviour in solving problems thought to require experts for their solution by utilizing computer programs that incorporate experts' heuristic reasoning. In this paper, the application of KBES to aid the design of ball and roller bearings is discussed. The precision rolling-element bearing of the twentieth century is a product of exacting technology and sophisticated science. A bearing supports radial and axial loads, at the same time allowing relative motion between two elements of a machine. Various requirements and steps in the design of ball and roller bearings are discussed. Equations are developed for the relevant design parameters and input into the expert system shell called VP-Expert. The expert system rules are also provided. (A)
Index Keywords: Artifical Intelligence

Title: A.I. means advanced informatics
Source title: Lecture Notes in Computer Science (including subseries Lecture Notes in Artificial Intelligence and Lecture Notes in Bioinformatics)
Affiliations: École Supédeure d’Électricité, Plateau de Moulon, Gif-sur-Yvette Cedex, 91192, France
Authors with affiliations: Hebenstreit, J., École Supédeure d’Électricité, Plateau de Moulon, Gif-sur-Yvette Cedex, 91192, France
Abstract: Artificial Intelligence is a generic name under which are gathered the problems for which we believe that a minimum of human intelligence is required for their solution. The set of these problems is not well defined in the sense that there is no formal procedure (algorithm) available to decide whether a problem does or not belong to that set mainly because there is no formal definition of human intelligence. By and large “intelligent machines” are still wishful thinking. However beyond and despite various fads and fashions, what Artifical Intelligence has brought to computer science is an increasing interest in types of problems which were not seriously studied before. This in turn has led to concepts, methods, techniques and tools which progressively have spread over all areas of computer science. It can thus be said that AI through the various theoretical and practical questions it has raised in many domains of Computer Science from formal logic to programming languages could be more properly called Advanced Informatics than Artificial Intelligence. By ways of consequence AI has also led to drastic changes of the contents of Computer Science Curricula which should be more properly called “Advanced Informatics Curricula”. © Springer-Verlag Berlin Heidelberg 1990.
Index Keywords: Artificial intelligence; Computer programming; Curricula; Education; Formal logic; Problem oriented languages; Artifical intelligence; Computer science curricula; Formal definition; Human intelligence; Informatics; Intelligent machine; Techniques and tools; Computer programming languages

Title: New artificial intelligence based method of inputting chinese characters for computer usage
Affiliations: Department of Computer Science, Queens College, City University of New York (CUNY), 65-30 Kissena Blvd, Flushing, New York, NY, 11367-0904, United States
Authors with affiliations: Chen, C., Department of Computer Science, Queens College, City University of New York (CUNY), 65-30 Kissena Blvd, Flushing, New York, NY, 11367-0904, United States; Rootenberg, J., Department of Computer Science, Queens College, City University of New York (CUNY), 65-30 Kissena Blvd, Flushing, New York, NY, 11367-0904, United States
Abstract: This paper presents a novel approach for solving the problems associated with inputting Chinese characters for processing by digital computers. The idea adopted in solving this problem is that of construction pattern recognition (CPR), and it is developed based on some concepts from the artifical intelligence (AI) field. The method presented here is markedly different from the currently existing inputting methodologies used when dealing with Chinese characters. In our approach, a Chinese character (word) is treated as a graph, rather than as a character of a language. It is then analysed, through pattern recognition, using some computing points associated with the Chinese character in the construction process used. The CPR approach has two basic advantages: (a) it is flexible, in as much as it allows the computer to accept both western and oriental languages; and (b) it offers the most user friendly inputting environment to the end user. © 1990 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.
Index Keywords: Codes, Symbolic; Computer Systems, Digital; Pattern Recognition Systems; Digital computers; Human computer interaction; Chinese Characters; Inputting Methodologies; Artificial Intelligence; Pattern recognition; Artifical intelligence; Chinese characters; Computer usages; Construction patterns; Construction process; End users; User friendly

Authors: Mira E., Buizza A., Magenes G., Manfrin M., Schmid R.
Title: Expert systems as a diagnostic aid in otoneurology
Affiliations: Department of Otorhinolaryngology, University of Pavia, Italy; Department of Computer and Systems Science, University of Pavia, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Mira, E., Department of Otorhinolaryngology, University of Pavia, Italy; Buizza, A., Department of Computer and Systems Science, University of Pavia, Italy; Magenes, G., Department of Computer and Systems Science, University of Pavia, Italy; Manfrin, M., Department of Otorhinolaryngology, University of Pavia, Italy; Schmid, R., Department of Computer and Systems Science, University of Pavia, Italy
Abstract: Expert systems (ES) are a new tool for information processing developed by the branch of computer science known as artifical intelligence. ES are capable of solving problems in a given domain by using the knowledge and emulating the behaviour of specialists in that field. ES can be used as powerful tools for education since they are able to justify their own conclusions and to make the underlying reasoning explicit. This paper presents ‘Vertigo’, an ES aimed at the classification and diagnosis of different forms of dizziness. It has been conceived mainly as a teaching tool in otoneurological departments. The rationale of this project, its development, the structure and the use of the system are described. So far, ‘Vertigo’ has been tested on more than 200 cases of dizziness and is presently being used by ENT residents during their otoneurology stage. © 1990 S. Karger AG, Basel.
Author Keywords: Dizziness; Expert systems; Vertigo

Title: Feature selection and extraction for well test interpretation by an artifical intelligence approach
Source title: Society of Petroleum Engineers of AIME, (Paper) SPE
Affiliations: Heriot-Watt Univ, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Stewart, G., Heriot-Watt Univ, United Kingdom; Du, Kui Fu, Heriot-Watt Univ, United Kingdom
Abstract: A technique for the automatic selection and extraction of features from a well test interpretation curve is described which provides a means for transforming a well test signal into a symbolic context; this is regarded as a first step in developing an automated or knowledge-based approach to interpreting transient pressure tests. It uses novel methods paralleling those frequently employed in solving artificial intelligence problems such as vision processing. The implementation of feature selection and extraction is carried out by the following steps: (1) Data preprocessing; (2) Segmentation; (3) Grouping; (4) Representation relationships between the segmented elements.
Index Keywords: Artificial Intelligence--Expert Systems; Computer Programming--Algorithms; Signal Processing; Feature Selection and Extraction; Segmentation Algorithm; Vision Processing; Oil Wells
Conference name: Proceedings: SPE Annual Technical Conference and Exhibition 1989

Title: Artificial intelligence in psychiatry: Issues and questions
Source title: Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology - Proceedings
Affiliations: Trinity Coll, Dep of Eng &, Comput Sci, Hartford, CT, USA
Authors with affiliations: Morelli, Ralph, Trinity Coll, Dep of Eng &, Comput Sci, Hartford, CT, USA
Abstract: Several recent research prototypes and applications are discussed with the goal of identifying key issues and open questions for further research and discussion. Special opportunities and challenges presented by the psychiatric domain are identified, and an attempt is made to relate artifical intelligence issues in the psychiatric domain with current trends in other domains. The author maintains that one of the most promising application areas is clinical monitoring, which, instead of giving advice, provides the clinician with information alerts calling attention to clinical situations that require the physician's attention. Another promising area identified is quality assurance monitoring, which represents an institutional or peer group activity to ensure that patients receive the best care possible.
Index Keywords: Biomedical Engineering--Computer Applications; Artificial Intelligence in Psychiatry; Computerized Psychotherapy; Psychiatric Research; Artificial Intelligence
Conference name: Images of the Twenty-First Century - Proceedings of the 11th Annual International Conference of the IEEE Engineering in Medicine and Biology Society. Part 2

Authors: Barreto J.M., Lefevre J., Noirhomme-Fraiture M., de Lima W.Celso
Title: Qualitative simulation in physiology with bond graphs
Affiliations: Inst d'Informatique, FNDP, Belgium
Authors with affiliations: Barreto, J.M., Inst d'Informatique, FNDP, Belgium; Lefevre, J., Inst d'Informatique, FNDP, Belgium; Noirhomme-Fraiture, M., Inst d'Informatique, FNDP, Belgium; de Lima, W.Celso, Inst d'Informatique, FNDP, Belgium
Abstract: The simulation of a physiological system involves the construction of a model, generally in the form of mathematical equations, the manipulation of this model to obtain the solution of the equations, and finally the interpretation of the result. In a qualitative simulation, in a certain sense, we go directly from the real system to the interpretation without use of the mathematical model. This approach was introduced using artifical intelligence techniques, where we try to reproduce a human reasoning explaining the behavior of the physical system. The main goal of the work is to present a methodology, based on bond graphs, and the causal stroke algorithm (CASA) to obtain the antecedent and consequent of rules, model that explains the functioning of a physiological system. To illustrate the methodology, a qualitative dynamic compliance model of a ventricle is discussed.
Index Keywords: Artificial Intelligence--Expert Systems; Mathematical Models; Mathematical Techniques--Fuzzy Sets; Approximate Reasoning; Bond Graphs; Physiological Models; Qualitative Physics; Biomedical Engineering

Title: Knowledge based system applications on EMC
Source title: IEEE International Symposium on Electromagnetic Compatibility
Affiliations: Society for Appl Microwave Electron, Eng & Res, Madras, India
Authors with affiliations: Surekha, M., Society for Appl Microwave Electron, Eng & Res, Madras, India; Patki, A.B., Society for Appl Microwave Electron, Eng & Res, Madras, India; Sudha, A.V., Society for Appl Microwave Electron, Eng & Res, Madras, India; Sekhar, G.S., Society for Appl Microwave Electron, Eng & Res, Madras, India; Radha, G., Society for Appl Microwave Electron, Eng & Res, Madras, India
Abstract: Applications of artifical intelligence (AI) techniques in various areas of electromagnetic compatibility (EMC) analysis are discussed. The significance of AI, the reason for EMC engineers to adopt AI, and the use of AI in the EMC domain are discussed in detail. A wire-to-wire coupling analysis program is discussed. In this program, if an expert's knowledge with all necessary details is imparted, then it becomes more effective. Transmitters, receivers, and propagation media can be modeled, and numerical calculations can be reduced to a large extent by using symbolic manipulation.

Title: Object-oriented model for building design and construction
Affiliations: Univ of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign, United States

Abstract: This paper describes the initial work done in developing a modelling environment which captures both functional and spatial aspects of a building, abstract and detailed descriptions, and the intent behind the decisions and results. The model is able to represent the physical objects comprising a building, the functional systems and subsystems made up of these physical objects, the spatial aspects of the structure, and the functional and spatial relationships between the various components of the structure.

Title: Impact of computers on sensory evaluation: past, present and future
Affiliations: Oliemans Punter and Partners BV Burgemeester Reigerstraat 89, 3581 KP Utrecht, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Roos, P.E., Oliemans Punter and Partners BV Burgemeester Reigerstraat 89, 3581 KP Utrecht, Netherlands
Abstract: Developments in hardware and software in the last decade have dramatically changed the role of computers in sensory analysis. Besides data-entry and data-analysis, personal computers are used more and more for data-collection, experimental design and panel-management. Tests are prepared on the personal computer, the questions are displayed on screens in the tasting booths, the subjects can enter their responses directly and the results can be available instantaneously. In the last five years, several systems for automated sensory analysis have been developed. In the coming years, computers will become more powerful, cheaper, faster, and will have more memory. Although it is not clear at this moment which operating system will become the standard for the next decade, the software will certainly be more user-friendly. Graphical-user-interfaces will change the way we interact with the computer. New approaches to software development, like object-oriented programming, artifical intelligence and relational database management systems will make it possible to use the computer for more aspects of sensory evaluation. It is important to identify the different tasks in the laboratory that can be automated and to look for the right tools to use. In view of the developments in the last decade, it is not advisable to wait for the ultimate solution. © 1989.
Author Keywords: automation; computers, sensory evaluation

Source title: Agenda for the 90's. Technical papers 1989 ASPRS/ACSM annual convention, Baltimore. Vol. 3

Authors with affiliations: Clark, B.P., Computer Sciences Corp., 8728 Colesville Road, Silver Spring, MD 20910, USA, United States
Abstract: Remote sensing technology has advanced significantly during the past 20 years. New instruments, better detectors, more sophisticated ground systems and expanded product types have resulted. Artifical Intelligence and Expert Systems have had a parallel growth during the past two decades. Using Landsat as a baseline for remotely sensed data, this paper discusses both technologies and the need to merge these disciplines where possible for ground processing systems of the future. -Author

Title: A discussion on some trends of geographic information systems
Affiliations: Dept of Geo & Ocean Sci, Nanjing Univ, China

Abstract: GIS has become an important component of a technical system applied to geography. To perform various types of spatial analysis represents a major aim in applications and research of GIS. The most important technical topic within the field of GIS concerns spatial data structures. The intergration of approaches and procedures within a single system is becoming increasingly evident. Great attention has been paid to research on standardization and artifical intelligence techniques. -from English summary

Title: Studies on artificial intelligence and expert systems in geography
Authors with affiliations: Tikunov, V.S.
Abstract: Research into artifical intelligence is reviewed briefly and four areas are identified. The most successful area - the creation of expert systems - is discussed in more detail. The structure of an expert system is described: knowledge base, machinery for deduction, systems for accumulating knowledge, systems for explaining and interacting with users. A simplified expert system is described in detail. The possible uses of expert systems in geography are noted. -translated by P.Cooke

Authors: Davis J.R., Nanninga P.M., Hoare J.R.L., Press A.J.
Title: Transferring scientific knowledge to natural resource managers using artificial intelligence concepts
Affiliations: CSIRO Division of Water Resources Research, Canberra, A.C.T. 2601, Australia; CSIRO Division of Forest Research, Canberra, A.C.T. 2600, Australia; Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service, Jabiru, North Territ. 5796, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Davis, J.R., CSIRO Division of Water Resources Research, Canberra, A.C.T. 2601, Australia; Nanninga, P.M., CSIRO Division of Water Resources Research, Canberra, A.C.T. 2601, Australia; Hoare, J.R.L., CSIRO Division of Forest Research, Canberra, A.C.T. 2600, Australia; Press, A.J., Australian National Parks and Wildlife Service, Jabiru, North Territ. 5796, Australia
Abstract: An expert system shell, GEM-II, has been developed specifically for classification problems in environmental management. Specialist information can be represented as production rules, mathematical models and time-independent facts held in a database. All information, i.e., the rules, models and facts, can be assigned to positions in Cartesian space. The shell has been coupled to a knowledge base containing information on fire behaviour and the effects of fire on vegetation in part of Kakadu National Park, Northern Australia. This system is now installed at the Park headquarters. The information has been derived from experiments run over ten years and from general experience of the region. The first part of the base contains a model of fire behaviour believed to be applicable throughout the Park; the second part (fire effects) is restricted to regions typified by the experimental site. The expert system will be run and assessed by Park managers over the next few years. The system is flexible and allows the managers to modify rules and change 'facts' as further knowledge of fire behaviour and effects becomes available and to add mathematical models of fire behaviour when these have been calibrated for northern Australia. Whilst the suitability of the system for the Park managers is yet to be fully assessed, it is already cler that expert systems can assist scientists to develop models of the processes they study. © 1989.
Index Keywords: artifical intelligence; environmental management; mathematical model; national park; Australia, Northern Territory, Kakadu National Park

Authors: Motomura M., Shirotori T., Ono H.
Title: Research on CAD system for hot forging die of aluminum
Source title: Journal of Japan Institute of Light Metals
Affiliations: Faculty of Science and Engineering, Waseda University, Shinjuku-ku, Tokyo, Japan; Graduate School, Waseda University, Shinjuku-ku, Tokyo, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Motomura, M., Faculty of Science and Engineering, Waseda University, Shinjuku-ku, Tokyo, Japan; Shirotori, T., Graduate School, Waseda University, Shinjuku-ku, Tokyo, Japan; Ono, H., Faculty of Science and Engineering, Waseda University, Shinjuku-ku, Tokyo, Japan
Abstract: Recently, topics of CAD systems have been partial to an achievement of difficulties. For example, some Artifical Intelligence CAD systems are only focused on an accomplishment of Artifical Intelligence techniques, but they may not consider what systems will be wanted in the practical field. We researched how CAD systems in the aluminum forging companies should be, and developed the CAD systems for them. The developed systems perform the billet estimate, drawings (CAD) and the die analysis with the slab method by a personal computer. This paper reports an example showing that more fundamental techniques greatly improve the designings. © 1989, The Japan Institute of Light Metals. All rights reserved.

Title: Some Lisp applications in surveying and mapping
Affiliations: School of Civil & Structural Engineering, Nanyang Technical Inst., Singapore
Authors with affiliations: Koo, T.K., School of Civil & Structural Engineering, Nanyang Technical Inst., Singapore
Abstract: The science of Artifical Intelligence (AI) is slowly making an impact in surveying and mapping. The central tool of AI is the symbolic language of Lisp. Unfortunately, this lingua franca of AI research and applications is unknown to most surveyors. This ignorance does not augur well for the image surveyors hope to project in the information age. But are there incentives to learning Lisp when the traditional languages of Fortran, Basic and Pascal have proved satisfactory for numerical work? This paper attempts to provide evidence to show that learning Lisp not only to open up new worlds of thinking in the near future, but that already there are routine applications in surveying and mapping. -Author
Index Keywords: artificial intelligence; computer language; Lisp; mapping; surveying

Authors: Matsushima Toshiyasu, Suzuki Joe, Inazumi Hiroshige, Hirasawa Shigeichi
Title: On uncertain logic based upon information theory
Affiliations: Waseda Univ, Tokyo, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Matsushima, Toshiyasu, Waseda Univ, Tokyo, Jpn; Suzuki, Joe, Waseda Univ, Tokyo, Jpn; Inazumi, Hiroshige, Waseda Univ, Tokyo, Jpn; Hirasawa, Shigeichi, Waseda Univ, Tokyo, Jpn
Abstract: Summary form only given, as follows. The authors propose a semantic generalized predicate logic that is based on probability theory and information theory for providing theoretical methods for processing uncertain knowledge in artifical intelligence (AI) applications. The basic concept of the proposed logic is that the interpretation of the well-formed formula (wff) containing uncertainty is represented by using conditional probability. By the interpretation model using the conditional probability, a lot of problems that are impossible to treat by conventional AI methods can be explained in terms of information theory. From the definition, the self-information of the wff, the mutual information between a couple of predicates, and information gain by the reasoning can be shown. Next, reasoning rules are evaluated using the information gain which expresses the difference between the prior information and the posterior information of the consequent wff. Finally, the authors give a new calculation method for reasoning that gives the most unbiased probability estimation, given the available evidence, and prove that the proposed method is optimal from the principle of maximum entropy, subject to the given marginal probability condition.
Index Keywords: Information Theory; Probability; Abstract Only; Conditional Probability; Semantic Generalized Predicate Logic; Unbiased Probability Estimation; Uncertain Logic; Artificial Intelligence
Sponsors: IEEE, Information Theory Group, New York, NY, USA;Inst of Electronics, Information & Communication Engineers of
Conference name: IEEE 1988 International Symposium on Information Theory - Abstracts of papers

Authors: Kabakcioglu A.M., Varshney P.K., Hartmann C.R.P.
Title: Artifical intelligence approach to PLA optimization
Source title: Proceedings - IEEE International Symposium on Circuits and Systems
Affiliations: Univ of Miami, FL, USA
Authors with affiliations: Kabakcioglu, A.M., Univ of Miami, FL, USA; Varshney, P.K., Univ of Miami, FL, USA; Hartmann, C.R.P., Univ of Miami, FL, USA
Abstract: Programmable-logic-array (PLA) optimization can be achieved by using heuristic two-level switching-function minimization algorithms. The authors introduce a novel approach to the heuristic-switching-function minimization. The approach is based on formulating the problem as a state-space search. Several heuristic evaluation functions are used to guide the search, which is realized by constructing a binary decision tree.

Title: Semantic control theory
Affiliations: Department of Systems Science and Mathematics, Washington University, St. Louis, MO 63130, United States
Authors with affiliations: Rodin, E.Y., Department of Systems Science and Mathematics, Washington University, St. Louis, MO 63130, United States
Abstract: An overview of a new methodology, involving the application of artifical intelligence techniques to the design and implementation of some decision and control systems, is given. © 1988.

References: Rodin, Lirov, Mittnik, McElhany, Wilbur, Artificial Intelligence in Air Combat Games (1987) Computers and Mathematics with Applications, 13, pp. 1-3; Lirov, Rodin, McElhany, Wilbur, Artificial Intelligence Modelling of Control Systems (1988) SIMULATION, 50, p. 1

Title: Artificial intelligence in chemistry
Affiliations: Department of Computing Science, University of Wollongong, P.O. Box 1144, Wollongong, NSW 2500, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Gray, N.A.B., Department of Computing Science, University of Wollongong, P.O. Box 1144, Wollongong, NSW 2500, Australia
Abstract: The techniques and tools of artificial intelligence are reviewed. Chemical problems can serve as test domains for the development of new artificial intelligence methods. Artificial intelligence techniques can also be applied to the solution of practical problems in chemistry. Applications in chemistry include problems where it is necessary to encode chemical expertise, and where chemistry is merely an additional domain to which standard artificial intelligence techniques can be applied. Programs exploiting encoded chemical expertise can assist in solving problems of structure elucidation, synthesis planning, and experiment design. Robotics methods based on artifical intelligence and expert systems can enhance the performance of chemical instrumentation. Systems understanding natural language could improve the handling of chemical information, and artificial intelligence techniques may extend the capabilities of computer-assisted instruction. © 1988.

Title: A review of critical points detection and line generalization algorithms
Affiliations: Dept. of Construction at Ferris State Univ., Big Rapids, Michigan, USA., United States
Authors with affiliations: Thapa, K., Dept. of Construction at Ferris State Univ., Big Rapids, Michigan, USA., United States
Abstract: There is a plethora of literature in various fields concerning the problem of finding critical points in digital lines and line generalization. Often times, researchers are unaware of the work of similar nature which is being done in different fields. Therefore, an attempt has been made to put together the literature available to solve the difficult problem of critical points detection and line generalization. In this paper, literature on critical points detection, line generalization and line smoothing collected from many different fields such as computer graphics, image processing, computer vision, electrical engineering, artifical intelligence, mathematics, pattern recognition and cartography is given. It is hoped that future researchers will benefit from such a work. -Author
Index Keywords: critical point detection; line generalisation algorithm

Title: Knowledge and reasoning in development control and urban design: an expert systems approach
Affiliations: School of Planning, Oxford Polytechnic, Headington, Oxford, OX3 OBP, UK., United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Leary, M.E., School of Planning, Oxford Polytechnic, Headington, Oxford, OX3 OBP, UK., United Kingdom
Abstract: Expert systems are computer programs that use knowledge and expertise in a particular field to solve complex problems. As such, they are a way of organising, formalising, and disseminating context-specific knowledge and problem-solving techniques. Attempts to formalise planning and design methods are reviewed and some parallels are proposed in the development of thought between one area of artificial intelligence (AI) research and planning theory. In the final part of the paper there is a discussion of how an expert systems approach, based on techniques developed in the field of artificial intelligence, can be used to investigate the nature of knowledge and expertise in urban design and development control. -from Author
Index Keywords: artifical intelligence; development control; expert systems; urban design

Authors: Scdano B.G., Cerrolaza M., Alarcon E.
Title: QL-CONST1: An expert system for quality level prediction in concrete structures
Affiliations: Escuela Tecnica Superior de lngenieros Industriales, Univenidad Politecnica de Madrid, c/Gutierrez Abascal, 2, Madrid 28006, Spain; lnstituto de Materiales y Modelos Estructurales, Universidad Central de Venezuela, Aptdo. Postal 50361, Caracas, 1050A, Venezuela
Authors with affiliations: Scdano, B.G., Escuela Tecnica Superior de lngenieros Industriales, Univenidad Politecnica de Madrid, c/Gutierrez Abascal, 2, Madrid 28006, Spain; Cerrolaza, M., lnstituto de Materiales y Modelos Estructurales, Universidad Central de Venezuela, Aptdo. Postal 50361, Caracas, 1050A, Venezuela; Alarcon, E., Escuela Tecnica Superior de lngenieros Industriales, Univenidad Politecnica de Madrid, c/Gutierrez Abascal, 2, Madrid 28006, Spain
Abstract: Current trends in the fields of artifical intelligence and expert systems are moving towards the exciting possibility of reproducing and simulating human expertise and expert behaviour into a knowledge base, coupled with an appropriate, partially ‘intelligent’, computer code. This paper deals with the quality level prediction in concrete structures using the helpful assistance of an expert system, QL-CONST1, which is able to reason about this specific field of structural engineering. Evidence, hypotheses and factors related to this human knowledge field have been codified into a knowledge base. This knowledge base has been prepared in terms of probabilities of the presence of either hypotheses or evidence and the conditional presence of both. Human experts in the fields of structural engineering and the safety of structures gave their invaluable knowledge and assistance to the construction of the knowledge base. Some illustrative examples for,the validation of the expert system behaviour are included. © 1988, Taylor & Francis Group, LLC. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: Bayesian inference; Expert systems; knowledge-based systems; quality control; reinforced concrete structures
Index Keywords: Artificial Intelligence--Expert Systems; Probability; Quality Control; Reliability; Bayesian Inference; Expert System QL-CONST1; Knowledge Based Systems; Reinforced Concrete Structures; Concrete Construction

Title: Patterns and contrasts in ophthalmic investigation
Affiliations: Department of Vision Sciences, Aston University, Aston Triangle, Birmingham, B4 7ET, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Drasdo, N., Department of Vision Sciences, Aston University, Aston Triangle, Birmingham, B4 7ET, United Kingdom
Abstract: The Snellen test has been the most popular clinical measurement of spatial vision for over a century, but it does not fully express the visual ability of an individual. For more analytical purposes the information capacity of the visual system may be assessed by tests of contrast sensitivity and peripheral vision. The visual system selectively reduces the spatial information content of the visual field to avoid overloading the limited capacity for perception and decision making in the brain. The ways in which this reduction occurs and the processing of spatial information is of interest in many disciplines, and theoretical knowledge has been accelerated by the study of artifical intelligence. These processes may be investigated in human subjects by psychophysical and electrophysiological techniques. This provides additional information for diagnostic purposes and will form the basis of new systems of clinical investigation. Copyright © 1988, Wiley Blackwell. All rights reserved

Title: Expert systems development in lisp and ada®
Source title: Proceedings of the 1987 Annual ACM SIGAda International Conference on Ada, SIGAda 1987
Affiliations: Avionics Systems Boeing Military Airplane Co, P.O. Box 7730, Wichita, 67277-7730, United States
Authors with affiliations: Walters, M.D., Avionics Systems Boeing Military Airplane Co, P.O. Box 7730, Wichita, 67277-7730, United States
Abstract: This paper addresses the development of an Artifical Intelligence expert system, which performs tasks normally performed by experts in a given domain. In particular, a two-language approach to expert systems development will be examined, i.e., using LISP for rapid prototyping and problem understanding, and a more structured language such as Ada for development of an embedded software product. The advantages of each language for expert system development are discussed, and the results from a case study are provided to illustrate the two-pass approach and the issues involved in conversion of LISP code to Ada.
Index Keywords: Embedded systems; Expert systems; LISP (programming language); Software prototyping; Artifical intelligence; Expert system development; Problem understanding; Structured language; Systems development; Ada (programming language)

Title: USING THE 'SUPERINTENDENT' EXPERT SYSTEM.
Affiliations: Heuristics Inc, Heuristics Inc
Authors with affiliations: Smith, Robin G., Heuristics Inc, Heuristics Inc; Larson, Brian, Heuristics Inc, Heuristics Inc
Abstract: The 'Superintendent' program by Heuristics is a powerful fourth generation artificial intelligence language. The program runs on a microcomputer, and can inference and act upon data obtained from real world I/O devices, or from the operator. The Superintendent package was developed to give the plant engineer the benefits of a real world expert system, without requiring that the engineer be familiar with artifical intelligence programming languages. Knowledge bases built for Superintendent use English-like language. Once built, the knowledge bases can be used for automatic process control, report generation, sequencing, analysis, or maintenance of standard operating procedures.
Index Keywords: COMPUTER PROGRAMMING LANGUAGES; COMPUTER PROGRAMS; CONTROL SYSTEMS; PROCESS CONTROL; 'SUPERINTENDENT' PROGRAM PACKAGE; ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE PROGRAMMING LANGUAGES; REPORT GENERATION; SEQUENCING; ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE

Conference name: Proceedings of the Instrumentation & Control Systems Conference and Exhibit.

Title: Intelligent Information Bank Systems - User Friendly Instruments for Information Transfer? . [INTELLIGENTE INFORMATIONSBANKSYSTEME - BENUTZERFREUNDLICHE INSTRUMENTE FUER DIE INFORMATIONSVERMITTLUNG?]
Authors with affiliations: Zelewski, Stephan
Abstract: An information crisis is derived from the exponential growth of the quantitative production of information, the qualitative worsening of the supply of information, and the insufficiently increased processing capacity among the users of information. Two concepts of information procuring institutions have recently emerged in order to solve this information problem. It is a matter of extra-company information brokers and intra-company units for procurement of information. The instrumental support of these institutions by means of information bank systems is studied in detail. Starting from the approach of cooperative user interfaces, the concept of intelligent information bank systems is developed with particular regard to fresh results of artifical intelligence. Possible effects on the user friendliness of information bank systems that may be caused by the realization of this concept are discussed.
Index Keywords: DATABASE SYSTEMS; INFORMATION RETRIEVAL SYSTEMS; INFORMATION BANK SYSTEMS; INFORMATION BROKERS; INFORMATION PROCUREMENT; INFORMATION SCIENCE

Authors: Bloom B.C., Epstein M.A., Mathis D.W., Wolfe W.J., Duane G.S., Magee M., Nathan M.J.
Title: Intertwining of teleoperation and computer vision
Source title: Proceedings of SPIE - The International Society for Optical Engineering
Affiliations: Martin Marietta Astronautics Group, P. 0. Box 179, Denver, CO, 80201, United States; Ball Aerospace, Boulder, CO, United States; University of Wyoming, Laramie, WY, United States; University of Colorado, Boulder, CO, United States
Authors with affiliations: Bloom, B.C., Martin Marietta Astronautics Group, P. 0. Box 179, Denver, CO, 80201, United States; Epstein, M.A., Martin Marietta Astronautics Group, P. 0. Box 179, Denver, CO, 80201, United States; Mathis, D.W., Martin Marietta Astronautics Group, P. 0. Box 179, Denver, CO, 80201, United States; Wolfe, W.J., Martin Marietta Astronautics Group, P. 0. Box 179, Denver, CO, 80201, United States; Duane, G.S., Ball Aerospace, Boulder, CO, United States; Magee, M., University of Wyoming, Laramie, WY, United States; Nathan, M.J., University of Colorado, Boulder, CO, United States
Abstract: In the rapid pursuit of automation, it is sometimes overlooked that an elaborate human-machine interplay is still necessary, despite the fact that a fully automated system, by definition, would not require a human interface. In the future, real-time sensing, intelligent processing, and dextrous manipulation will become more viable, but until then it is necessary to use humans for many critical processes. It is not obvious, however, how automated subsystems could account for human intervention, especially if a philosophy of “pure” automation dominates the design. Teleoperation, by contrast, emphasizes the creation of hardware pathways (e.g., hand-controllers, exoskeletons) to quickly communicate low-level control data to various mechanisms, while providing sensory feedback in a format suitable for human consumption (e.g., stereo displays, force reflection), leaving the “intelligence” to the human. These differences in design strategy, both hardware and software, make it difficult to tie automation and teleoperation together, while allowing for graceful transitions at the appropriate times. In no area of artifical intelligence is this problem more evident than in computer vision. Teleoperation typically uses video displays (monochrome/color, monoscopic/stereo) with contrast enhancement and gain control without any digital processing of the images. However, increases in system performance such as automatic collision avoidance, path finding, and object recognition depend on computer vision techniques. Basically, computer vision relies on the digital processing of the images to extract low-level primitives such as boundaries and regions that are used in higher-level processes for object recognition and positions. Real-time processing of complex environments is currently unattainable, but there are many aspects of the processing that are useful for situation assessment, provided it is understood the human can assist in the more time-consuming steps. This paper maps out the connections between computer vision and teleoperation, pointing to a new phase in the ongoing research in “supervised” or “semiautomatic” systems. © 1987 SPIE.
Index Keywords: Automation; Computer hardware; Computer vision; Exoskeleton (Robotics); Image enhancement; Mobile robots; Object recognition; Remote control; Sensory feedback; Artifical intelligence; Complex environments; Computer vision techniques; Contrast Enhancement; Dextrous manipulation; Hardware and software; Intelligent processing; Situation assessment; Stereo image processing
