Title: Low level architecture for the new eave vehicle
Source title: Proceedings of the 1987 5th International Symposium on Unmanned Untethered Submersible Technology, UUST 1987
Affiliations: Marine Systems Engineering Laboratory, University of New Hampshire, United States
Authors with affiliations: Jalbert, J., Marine Systems Engineering Laboratory, University of New Hampshire, United States
Abstract: KB/EAVE (Knowledge-Based/Experimental Autonomous Vehicle) is a third generation autonomous untethered submersible utilizing state-of-the-art processors, operating systems, sensors, and artifical intelligence concepts. Two such vehicles have been designed and fabricated and are currently undergoing laboratory and field tests (Figure 1). They have the capability to communicate and cooperate with each other as well as plan and replan their missions in real time if circumstances and events so dictate. The KB/EAVE vehicle architecture can be divided into two components called high level and low level (Figure 2). The high level architecture described in A Blackboard Based System for Context Mission Planning in An Autonomous Vehicle by S. Chappell in these proceedings includes: Data Assessment, Situation Assessment, Supervisor and Guidance. The low level architecture includes Effector Manager, Sensor Manager, and System Monitor. This paper will describe the low level architecture, the interaction between the high level and low level architecture, as well as a description of vehicle capabilities. © 1987 Marine Systems Engineering Lab.
Index Keywords: Architecture; Computer architecture; Knowledge based systems; Managers; Submersibles; Artifical intelligence; Data assessment; High level architecture; Mission planning; Situation assessment; State of the art; Third generation; Vehicle architecture; Autonomous vehicles
Conference name: 5th International Symposium on Unmanned Untethered Submersible Technology, UUST 1987

Title: Phase transitions in artificial intelligence systems
Affiliations: Xerox Palo Alto Research Center, Palo Alto, CA 94304, United States
Authors with affiliations: Huberman, B.A., Xerox Palo Alto Research Center, Palo Alto, CA 94304, United States; Hogg, T., Xerox Palo Alto Research Center, Palo Alto, CA 94304, United States
Abstract: We predict that large-scale artificial intelligence systems and cognitive models will undergo sudden phase transitions from disjointed parts into coherent structures as their topological connectivity increases beyond a critical value. These situations, ranging from production systems to semantic net computations, are characterized by event horizons in space-time that determine the range of causal connections between processes. At transition, these event horizons undergo explosive changes in size. This phenomenon, analogous to phase transitions in nature, provides a new paradigm with which to analyze the behavior of large-scale computation and determine its generic features. © 1987.

Title: PROGRAMMER'S APPRENTICE PROJECT.
Affiliations: MIT, Cambridge, MA, USA, MIT, Cambridge, MA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Rich, Charles, MIT, Cambridge, MA, USA, MIT, Cambridge, MA, USA
Abstract: The goal of the Programmer's Apprentice Project is to develop a theory of how expert programmers analyze, synthesize, modify, explain, specify, verify, and document programs. This research goal overlaps both artifical intelligence and software engineering. Viewed as research in artificial intelligence, we have chosen programming as a domain in which to study fundamental issues of knowledge representation and reasoning. Viewed as research in software engineering, we seek to automate the programming process by applying techniques from artificial intelligence. The project consists of two principal lines of activity. One is concerned with developing knowledge representations and reasoning techniques motivated by features of the programming task. The second line is the implementation of experimental systems to demonstrate the feasibility of various kinds of programming automation.
Index Keywords: ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE - Expert Systems; EXPERT PROGRAMMERS; KNOWLEDGE REPRESENTATION; LANGUAGE-INDEPENDENT REPRESENTATION; PROGRAMMER'S APPRENTICE; REASONING; SUMMARY ONLY; COMPUTER PROGRAMMING

Title: AVAILABLE AND MISSING AI-TOOLS.
Authors with affiliations: Hatvany, J.
Abstract: This is an attempted survey of the AI tools available for use with manufacturing systems and those which manufacturing systems designers need, but which are not yet available to them. A scenario is presented of the intelligent manufacturing systems of the future and there is a discussion of how to develop skills, attitudes, motivations and organizations to increase the efficiency of mutual communication between AI people and manufacturing engineers.

Authors: Denton Richard V., Pekelsma Nicholas J.
Title: INTERACTIVE MISSION PLANNING WORKSTATION.
Source title: Record - IEEE PLANS, Position Location and Navigation Symposium
Affiliations: TAU Corp, Los Gatos, CA, USA, TAU Corp, Los Gatos, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Denton, Richard V., TAU Corp, Los Gatos, CA, USA, TAU Corp, Los Gatos, CA, USA; Pekelsma, Nicholas J., TAU Corp, Los Gatos, CA, USA, TAU Corp, Los Gatos, CA, USA
Abstract: An novel route-finding method has been developed which enables ground vehicle path planning across potentially hostile terrain. Routes are generated with the support of artifical intelligence techniques. Color displays of the route along any location of interest are being developed to provide for both top-down and perspective views allowing a direct correlation between views. The applicability of the concept has been successfully demonstrated through analysis of realistic scenarios and generation of representative color views and displays. The technique results in realistic routes over a network of roads and off-road regions. Route selection criteria include tradeoffs among transit speeds, threat laydown including terrain masking effects, and intervisibility effects when threat locations are highly uncertain. The pertinent concepts to automatic path planning, display generation, and vehicle monitoring are explained. The engineering feasibility of this technique is discussed with emphasis on providing extremely rapid feedback to the user of the system.
Index Keywords: ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE - Applications; COMPUTER SYSTEMS, DIGITAL - Interactive Operation; GROUND VEHICLE PATH PLANNING; ROUTE FINDING METHOD; MILITARY VEHICLES

Title: ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE: A NEW TOOL FOR THE WIRE INDUSTRY.
Authors with affiliations: Miller, Richard K.
Abstract: Although the commercialization of artificial intelligence began only about two years ago, the progress in developing applications for business and industry has been dramatic. Approximately 100 firms offer AI software and services, and about an equal number of large corporations have established in-house AI departments. A strong future is forecast for AI. Predictions indicate that half of the computers sold in 1993 will contain artifical intelligence components rather than arithmetic components, and will be called 'logic machines. ' By 1993, annual revenues for AI software, hardware and services are projected to reach 8 billion.
Index Keywords: COMPUTER PROGRAMMING LANGUAGES - LISP; ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE; EXPERT SYSTEMS FOR CAD/CAM; WIRE MILLS

Title: Megaflops and CAD/CAM in Metals Processing
Authors with affiliations: Szekely, J.; Foreman, F.
Abstract: Computer-aided modeling (CAM), computer-aided design (CAD) and manufacture, artifical intelligence and robotization have become frequently used terms in connection with manufacturing operations. Within this context, the question naturally arises as to what extent these ideas have taken root in today's metals processing and to what extent these concepts will develop in the future. This overview presentation examines the types of problems where major advances have been made through modeling. Also featured is a list of current software packages available as well as hardware. A discussion of rational mathematical modeling strategies in a materials processing environment is also included. © 1986 TMS.

Abstract: This article presents a brief history of artificial intelligence research at the Rand Corporation. It traces the major accomplishments in AI at Rand with particular emphasis on Rand's research during the past decade. The references highlight the major Rand documents on AI and related subjects. The discussion covers human-oriented environments, expert systems, and knowledge-based simulation.

Title: SCADA: WESTERN EUROPEAN STYLE.
Affiliations: Logica Energy Systems, Houston, TX,, USA, Logica Energy Systems, Houston, TX, USA
Authors with affiliations: Wike, A., Logica Energy Systems, Houston, TX,, USA, Logica Energy Systems, Houston, TX, USA
Abstract: SCADA developments in Western Europe is presented in the article. Leak detection, transient hydraulic modelling, integrated communications, contract optimization and artificial intelligence are the topics covered in the article. One goal of operators has been to integrate modeling systems with conventional SCADA system such that the models can be used by dispatchers rather than engineers. Although speech recognition systems have been available for some time, only recently have continuous speech recogintion systems where key words are extracted from continuous spoken streams been developed. They have already appeared as optional MMI components in SCADA systems.

Authors: Rosis F.D., Pizzutilo S., Greco D.
Title: MICRO-IDEA: Improving decisions in epidemiological analysis by a microcomputer
Source title: Informatics for Health and Social Care
Affiliations: Istituto de Scienze dell'Informazione, Universita Bari, Italy; Laboratorio di Epidemiologia, Istituto Superiore di Sanità, Roma, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Rosis, F.D., Istituto de Scienze dell'Informazione, Universita Bari, Italy; Pizzutilo, S., Istituto de Scienze dell'Informazione, Universita Bari, Italy; Greco, D., Laboratorio di Epidemiologia, Istituto Superiore di Sanità, Roma, Italy
Abstract: A microcomputer system has been designed to promote uniform and correct epidemiological data handling in the Local Health Units of the National Health Service in Italy. The system allows to define files of any format, to perform the common data manipulation procedures and to make simple statistical analyses. Two modules, based on artifical intelligence techniques, give the possibility to input from 'experts' and to update domain-specific knowledge concerning facts which characterize the application area covered by the file, and some consultation models which represent the reasoning to follow when solving problems of epidemiological data analysis. A decision support module allows an inexpert user to have access to these models, and to be guided in the choice of the appropriate procedure. The menu-driven interactive approach insures a friendly user-to-system interface, and entails a little training for effective use by health workers inexpert in informatics. © 1986 Informa UK Ltd All rights reserved: reproduction in whole or part not permitted.

Title: Three interpretations of mechanisms of defense
Affiliations: Psychologisch Laboratorium, Universiteit van Amsterdam, 1018 XA Amsterdam, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Van Heerden, J., Psychologisch Laboratorium, Universiteit van Amsterdam, 1018 XA Amsterdam, Netherlands
Abstract: Psychologists readily say that people can be involved in actions of unconscious defense in order to protect themselves against the threat of ambiguous thoughts and wishes. It is still not clear, however, to what extent one can say that in such cases people's behavior is caused by mechanisms of defense functioning as specific mental devices. The concept of a mechanism of defense needs further clarification. It is argued here that psychology may benefit from a tripartite distinction borrowed from Dennett's work on artifical intelligence (1978). This distinction may provide a better understanding of the explanatory power of the concept 'mechanism of defense'. Following Dennett one can adopt the intentional stance, the design stance or the physical stance, in case one wants to understand and predict the behavior of people involved in unconscious, defensive acts.
Index Keywords: central nervous system; defense; human; theoretical study

Title: U. S AIR FORCE TEMPLAR PROJECT STATUS AND OUTLOOK.
Affiliations: TRW, Defense Systems Group, Redondo, Beach, CA, USA, TRW, Defense Systems Group, Redondo Beach, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Press, Barry, TRW, Defense Systems Group, Redondo, Beach, CA, USA, TRW, Defense Systems Group, Redondo Beach, CA, USA
Abstract: The TEMPLAR, the US Air Force tactical expert mission planner, project is discussed, under development for the Air Force Rome Air Development Center (RADC). TEMPLAR is the first major Air Force application of artifical intelligence (AI) technology to produce an advanced development model (ADM) of a decision aid which will be demonstrated by the operational forces. TEMPLAR will build on technologies demonstrated by RADC, the Mitre Corp. , and the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA) to incorporate natural language understanding, constraint and expert system-based planning, and advanced man-macine interface (MMI) techniques. The TEMPLAR ADM will assist Air Force mission planners in developing the Air Tasking Order (ATO) which defines targets, missions, aircraft assignment, weaponeering, and other data sent to the wings. The ADM will have near-operatioal functionality and packaging. During the development it will be demonstrated and evaluated at Blue Flag and AirLand Battle Management exercises, followed by delivery and installation in the RADC Battle Management Laboratory.
Index Keywords: DECISION THEORY AND ANALYSIS - Military Purposes; SYSTEMS SCIENCE AND CYBERNETICS - Man Machine Systems; AIR FORCE MISSION PLANNING; NATURAL LANGUAGE SYSTEMS; TACTICAL EXPERT MISSION PLANNER; TEMPLAR; ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE
Sponsors: IEEE Computer Soc, Western Committee, Los Alamitos, CA, USA;IEEE, Los Angeles Council, Los Angeles, CA, USA
Conference name: Proceedings - WESTEX-86: IEEE Western Conference on Knowledge-Based Engineering and Expert Systems.

Title: Expert systems in plant engineering.
Authors with affiliations: Donoghue, J.A.
Abstract: The next decade is likely to see significant changes in the methods of use of computers in all fields of industry. Some of the new techniques will involve artifical intelligence and one such form is currently described under the heading of 'Expert computing systems'. This paper discusses such systems and describes how they can benefit fault finding in complex plant engineering situations. (A)

Title: PROCEEDINGS OF THE 1985 SUMMER COMPUTER SIMULATION CONFERENCE.
Source title: Proceedings of the Summer Computer Simulation Conference
Authors with affiliations: Anon
Abstract: Proceedings incorporates 138 papers that are subdivided into 16 groups dealing with: simulation methods, computer systems, simulation credibility and validation, physical and engineering sciences, data communication, chemical sciences, energy, biomedical simulation, environmental sciences, management, social sciences, training and research simulators, government simulation/computation activities, CAD/CAM and manufacturing systems, artifical intelligence, simulation of discrete systems, and flight simulation systems. Topics considered include programming languages, simulation models, control systems, optimization, military engineering, molecular dynamics, numerical integration, satellites, and missiles.
Index Keywords: ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE; CHEMICAL REACTIONS; CONTROL SYSTEMS; MATHEMATICAL TECHNIQUES; MILITARY ENGINEERING; DATA COMMUNICATION; EIREV; RESEARCH SIMULATORS; SIMULATION LANGUAGES; SIMULATION MODELS; VALIDATION PROCEDURES; COMPUTER SIMULATION
Sponsors: Soc for Computer Simulation, San Diego, CA, USA
Conference name: Proceedings of the 1985 Summer Computer Simulation Conference.

Title: ADVANCED INFORMATION EXTRACTION TECHNOLOGY FOR APPLICATION TO HIGH-DATA-VOLUME REMOTE SENSING MISSIONS.
Source title: Digest - International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium (IGARSS)
Affiliations: Univ of Massachusetts, Remote, Sensing Cent, Amherst, MA, USA, Univ of Massachusetts, Remote Sensing Cent, Amherst, MA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Huguenin, R.L., Univ of Massachusetts, Remote, Sensing Cent, Amherst, MA, USA, Univ of Massachusetts, Remote Sensing Cent, Amherst, MA, USA
Abstract: A new technology has been developed that can extract peak positions, widths, and intensities from spectral distributions with higher precision, accuracy, and sensitivity than previously achieved. The technique utilizes a multiple high-order derivative analysis algorithm embedded in a spectral pattern recognition and artificial intelligence control system. The spectral pattern recognition capability provides a required predetection of signal and noise characteristics, and the artifical intelligence capability continually adjusts and optimizes the peak detection and noise filtering parameters to the predetected signal and noise characteristics. This allows the peak detection algorithm to work on data of highly variable quality and signal characteristics under full automation. Application to remote sensing missions is discussed.
Index Keywords: ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE; COMPUTER PROGRAMMING - Algorithms; PATTERN RECOGNITION; SIGNAL FILTERING AND PREDICTION; FEATURE EXTRACTION; REMOTE SENSING
Sponsors: IEEE Geoscience & Remote Sensing Soc, New York, NY, USA;IEEE Antennas & Propagation Soc, New York, NY, USA;IEEE Oceanic Engineering Soc, New York, NY, USA;American Geophysical Union, Washington, DC, USA;European Assoc of Remote Sensing Lab;et al
Conference name: Digest - 1985 International Geoscience and Remote Sensing Symposium (IGARSS '85). Remote Sensing Instrumentation: Technology for Science and Applications.

Title: SELF-TUNING CONTROLLERS BASED ON EXPERT SYSTEMS AND ARTIFICAL INTELLIGENCE.
Affiliations: Foxboro Great Britian Ltd, Redhill, Engl, Foxboro Great Britian Ltd, Redhill, Engl
Authors with affiliations: Higham, E.H., Foxboro Great Britian Ltd, Redhill, Engl, Foxboro Great Britian Ltd, Redhill, Engl
Abstract: Conventional three-term controllers have been used extensively in the process industries for many decades and, in general, their performance is entirely adequate. However, in some instances, the variability of the process characteristics makes it difficult to preset the controller parameters so as to achieve an acceptable performance and the processes are therefore operated under manual control. The majority of studies to resolve these difficulties have been based on establishing some form of mathematical model of the processes, but this approach has not only revealed the difficulty of obtaining the necessary basic data but also that non-linearities and variability of the process parameters restrict the usefulness of this approach. An alternative approach involving a more pragmatic method has also been developed during the past two decades. Some of these are described in the cited references and most of them make use of 'expert systems' by incorporating the experience and knowledge of skilled control engineers combined with 'artificial intelligence' which reflects the 'classic' response of a process, expressed in terms of lumped parameters. The evolution of the self-tuning controller is described, in this paper.
Index Keywords: ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE - Expert Systems; CONTROL SYSTEMS, THREE TERM; PATTERN RECOGNITION; PROCESS CONTROL; EXACT SELF-TUNING CONTROLLER; MAXIMUM ALLOWABLE DAMPING; MAXIMUM WAIT TIME; PID CONTROLLERS; SELF-TUNING CONTROLLERS; CONTROL SYSTEMS, SELF ADJUSTING
Sponsors: Inst of Chemical Engineers, Yorkshire Branch, Bradford, Engl;Inst of Chemical Engineers, Process Control Subject Group, Rugby,;IEE, London, Engl
Conference name: Advances in Process Control.

Title: ROLE OF USER MODELING IN NATURAL LANGUAGE INTERFACE DESIGN.
Authors with affiliations: Carbonell, Jaime G.
Abstract: This article focuses on available methods for modeling user behavior and discusses the strengths and weaknesses of several. It specifically looks at quantitative-empirical methods and a variety of cognitive modeling techniques. It suggests that natural language systems designers determine just how familiar a user is with the functionality of the underlying target system, the long-term commitment of the user, the range of sophistication of the expected user population, and the amount of computer-initiated versus mixed-initiative dialogue that should be made part of the system-user interaction. The article then turns to the criteria for designing and evaluating friendly natural language interfaces. It suggests that friendly interfaces have broad syntactic coverage capabilities, provide task-oriented semantic coverage, are flexible in the presence of 'extra-grammaticality', are resilient, and transportable.
Index Keywords: COMPUTER PROGRAMMING LANGUAGES; NATURAL LANGUAGE INTERFACE DESIGN; ARTIFICAL INTELLIGENCE

Authors: McGraw Bruce A., McGraw Karen L.
Title: MILITARY APPLICATIONS OF ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE TECHNOLOGY.
Affiliations: Texas Instruments Inc, Equipment, Group, McKinney, TX, USA, Texas Instruments Inc, Equipment Group, McKinney, TX, USA
Authors with affiliations: McGraw, Bruce A., Texas Instruments Inc, Equipment, Group, McKinney, TX, USA, Texas Instruments Inc, Equipment Group, McKinney, TX, USA; McGraw, Karen L., Texas Instruments Inc, Equipment, Group, McKinney, TX, USA, Texas Instruments Inc, Equipment Group, McKinney, TX, USA
Abstract: The Artifical Intelligence Lab of Texas Instruments Equipment Group is involved in the military applications of artificial intelligence technology. The authors explain artificial intelligence, provide examples of some of its uses, and detail some of the reasons the technology is well suited to military applications. Specific projects and programs that exemplify military applications of artificial intelligence technology are outlined. The areas discussed are: advanced ship classification; the F-16 Emergency Procedures Expert Systems; the Pilot's Associate; the Force Requirements Expert System; Circuit Analysis Program (CAP); database technology applications; cognitive requirements for cockpit automation; the Enhanced Terrain Masking Penetration program; and the Light Helicopter Experimental program.
Index Keywords: COCKPIT AUTOMATION; SHIP CLASSIFICATION; ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE
Sponsors: IEEE, New York, NY, USA
Conference name: 1985 IEEE Region 5 Conference.

Title: Artificial intelligence applied to diagnostics.
Authors with affiliations: Hartwell, R.E.
Abstract: Research into the use of artifical intelligence to enhance the detection of faults and the diagnosis of multiple failure conditions on U.S. Army tactical vehicles is reported. The approach uses existing troubleshooting knowledge (in the form of programmed automated test logic) as the basis for an expert system. A model of vehicle systems to be implemented on a field portable microprocessor test system, the Simplified Test Equipment, to demonstrate that the technique is both practical and can be realized on a small field portable test set is described. (A)

Title: APPLIED ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE FOR STRUCTURAL ENGINEERING ANALYSIS AND DESIGN.
Source title: Proceedings of the International Offshore Mechanics and Arctic Engineering Symposium
Affiliations: MIT, Dep of Civil Engineering,, Cambridge, MA, USA, MIT, Dep of Civil Engineering, Cambridge, MA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Connor, J.J., MIT, Dep of Civil Engineering,, Cambridge, MA, USA, MIT, Dep of Civil Engineering, Cambridge, MA, USA; Finn, G.A., MIT, Dep of Civil Engineering,, Cambridge, MA, USA, MIT, Dep of Civil Engineering, Cambridge, MA, USA
Abstract: Recent developments in artifical intelligence have shown that it is possible to incorporate within a computer program intelligence characteristics that have heretofore been exhibited only by humans and utilize a knowledge base to simulate expertise. These expert programs have enormous potential for raising the level of performance of non-specialists and avoiding errors due to inexperience. The key element of an expert system is its knowledge base, which contains the wisdom accumulated by expert practitioners. This paper presents an overview of the current developments in expert systems for engineering analysis and design, identifies the types of knowledge desirable for structural problem solving systems, and describes a preliminary version of an expert system intended for design verification.
Index Keywords: BEAMS AND GIRDERS - Design; COMPUTER PROGRAMMING LANGUAGES - Applications; STRUCTURAL ANALYSIS - Computer Aided Analysis; SYSTEMS SCIENCE AND CYBERNETICS - Artificial Intelligence; ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE; CAD; EXPERT SYSTEMS; STRUCTURAL ENGINEERING ANALYSIS; STRUCTURAL DESIGN

Title: SOLAR WIND AND BEYOND.
Affiliations: Aerospace Corp, El Segundo, CA, USA, Aerospace Corp, El Segundo, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Rechtin, Eberhardt, Aerospace Corp, El Segundo, CA, USA, Aerospace Corp, El Segundo, CA, USA
Abstract: Taking von Karman's stories in his 'The Wind and Beyond' as a starting point, the author tells of some of the surprises and lessons learned in the engineering of space systems. The lessons cover orbits and momentum, navigation and time, thermodynamics, drag in space, the local environment, the solar wind and radiation, materials and lubricants, sensors, artifical intelligence, recovery operations and an amendment to Murphy's Law.
Index Keywords: SATELLITES; SENSORS; SOLAR RADIATION; SPACE FLIGHT; SPACECRAFT; CONSERVATION OF ANGULAR MOMENTUM; DRAG IN SPACE; ORBITS AND MOMENTUM; SOLAR WIND; SPACE RESEARCH
Sponsors: AIAA, New York, NY, USA
Conference name: AIAA 23rd Aerospace Sciences Meeting.

Title: HIERARCHY FOR CLASSIFYING AI IMPLICATIONS.
Source title: Proceedings of the Annual Conference of the Association for Computing Machinery
Affiliations: Univ of California, Santa Cruz, CA,, USA, Univ of California, Santa Cruz, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Pohl, Ira, Univ of California, Santa Cruz, CA,, USA, Univ of California, Santa Cruz, CA, USA
Abstract: Artifical Intelligence is rapidly emerging from the laboratory into the marketplace. Industrial robots are cost effective in a wide range of manufacturing tasks. Expert systems are commercially available and scientifically useful. Sophisticated chess machines are routinely sold in retail outlets. Assaulted by the unprecedented pace of these developments, society is confronted with assimilating these 'apparently-intelligent' artifacts. This paper will view these developments in the context of a hierarchy for classifying social impact. We examine to what extent does the appearance of apparently-intelligent machines produce a paradigmatic shift in how society defines itself and its social relations to these machines. Our analysis is performed in the framework of a taxonomy for segregating the continuum of effects that occur when advanced computer technology impacts society.
Index Keywords: DISLOCATING SHIFTS; EXPERT SYSTEMS; METHODOLOGICAL SHIFTS; PARADIGMATIC SHIFTS; SYSTEMS SCIENCE AND CYBERNETICS
Sponsors: ACM, New York, NY, USA
Conference name: Proceedings of the 1984 Annual Conference of the Association for Computing Machinery: The Fifth Generation Challenge.

Title: NEW APPROACH TO OPTICAL INFORMATION PROCESSING BASED ON THE HOPFIELD MODEL.
Affiliations: California Inst of Technology,, Pasadena, CA, USA, California Inst of Technology, Pasadena, CA, USA
Authors with affiliations: Psaltis, Demetri, California Inst of Technology,, Pasadena, CA, USA, California Inst of Technology, Pasadena, CA, USA; Farhat, Nabil, California Inst of Technology,, Pasadena, CA, USA, California Inst of Technology, Pasadena, CA, USA
Abstract: We describe two possible optical implementations of the model that has been recently proposed by Hopfield to describe neural networks. The operations required for its implementation (a global linearity, and a local uniform non-linearity) are well matched to the capabilities of optical processors. The insensitivity of the Hopfield model to almost any type of implementation error, and its soft-fail property facilitates a practical optical implementation. This model provides a method for associative optical storage of binary data and creates the possibility for optical techniques to be applied in areas such as artifical intelligence and data flow computers. Perhaps the most obvious application of such an optical processor is in pattern recognition.
Index Keywords: ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE; BINARY DATA; DATA FLOW COMPUTERS; HOPFIELD MODEL; IMPLEMENTATION ERRORS; NEURAL NETWORKS; OPTICAL INFORMATION PROCESSING; OPTICAL DATA PROCESSING
Sponsors: Int Commission for Optics, Delft, Neth;Chemical Soc of Japan, Jpn;Inst of Electrical Engineers of Japan, Jpn;Inst of Electronics & Communication Engineers of Japan, Jpn;IEEE, Int Optical Computing Conference, New York, NY, USA;et al
Conference name: 13th Congress of the International Commission for Optics, Optics in Modern Science and Technology, Conference Digest.

Authors: Smith T.R., Star J.L., Dubayah R.
Title: Applying artificial intelligence to large networks.
Source title: Activities of the Remote Sensing Information Sciences Research Group
Authors with affiliations: Smith, T.R.; Star, J.L.; Dubayah, R.
Abstract: The use of artifical intelligence to access and process geographicaly dispersed data sets with the use of geographically distributed software is examined. This requires capabilities in the areas of distributed data base management, long-haul networking, information presentation, distributed problem solving and artificial intelligence. In particular, the Pilot Land Data System, the Pilot Ocean Data System, and the Pilot Climate Data Base Management System (as well as a proposed Global Resource Information System) are structured as large computer networks. The techniques of artificial intelligence are discussed as they apply in distributed problem solving. -from STAR, 22(21), 1984

Title: STRATEGIC COMPUTING: A STRATEGIC PLAN FOR THE DEVELOPMENT OF MACHINE-INTELLIGENCE TECHNOLOGY AND ITS APPLICATION TO CRITICAL PROBLEMS IN DEFENSE.
Affiliations: Defense Advanced Research Projects, Agency, Washington, DC, USA, Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, Washington, DC, USA
Authors with affiliations: Conway, Lynn, Defense Advanced Research Projects, Agency, Washington, DC, USA, Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency, Washington, DC, USA
Abstract: To meet the challenge of certain critical problems in defense, the Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency (DARPA) is initiating an important new program in Strategic Computing. By seizing an opportunity to leverage recent advances in artificial intelligence, computer science, and microelectronics, the Agency plans to create a new generation of 'machine-intelligence technology. ' This new technology will have unprecedented capabilities, and promises to increase our national security and our economic strength as it emerges during the coming decade.
Index Keywords: COMING DECADE; COMPUTER SCIENCE; ECONOMIC STRENGTH; MACHINE-INTELLIGENCE; MICROELECTRONICS; STRATEGIC COMPUTING; ARTIFICAL INTELLIGENCE

Title: APPLICATION OF ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE PROGRAMMING TECHNIQUES TO THE DEVELOPMENT OF AN EXPERT SYSTEM FOR TUNING A TRIPLE QUADRUPOLE MASS SPECTROMETER.

Abstract: At Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory (LLNL), a triple quadrupole mass spectrometer (TQMS) has been designed and built which has all operational parameters under computer control using a DEC LSI-11/23 system. The ultimate goal has been to use this system as a prototype for 'knowledge-based' instrument control, i. e. and 'intelligent' instrument.

Title: Artifical Intelligence: From Wallflower to Rising Star. [KUENSTLICHE INTELLIGENZ: VOM MAUERBLUEMCHEN ZUR STAR-DISZIPLIN.]
Authors with affiliations: Hofer, Rudolf
Abstract: This article describes the development of artificial intelligence (AI) in expert or information systems. The author also looks at their fields of application, explains their chances on the market and deals with the possibility of use on personal computers.
Index Keywords: COMPUTERS, DIGITAL; EXPERT SYSTEMS; PERSONAL COMPUTERS; SYSTEMS SCIENCE AND CYBERNETICS

Authors: Schnupp P., Schmauch C., Leibrandt U.
Title: What is Prolog. [WAS IST PROLOG?]
Affiliations: InterFace GmbH, Munich, West Ger, InterFace GmbH, Munich, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Schnupp, P., InterFace GmbH, Munich, West Ger, InterFace GmbH, Munich, West Ger; Schmauch, C., InterFace GmbH, Munich, West Ger, InterFace GmbH, Munich, West Ger; Leibrandt, U., InterFace GmbH, Munich, West Ger, InterFace GmbH, Munich, West Ger
Abstract: Prolog is the first viable language for 'non-algorithmic' logic programming. It does not describe the 'how to do' but 'what it is'. This characteristic has made Prolog a suitable tool for writing expert systems and for other areas in artifical intelligence.
Index Keywords: SYSTEMS SCIENCE AND CYBERNETICS - Artificial Intelligence; PROLOG LANGUAGE; COMPUTER PROGRAMMING LANGUAGES

Title: FLUID THERAPY CONSULTATION SYSTEM BASED ON KNOWLEDGE ENGINEERING TECHNIQUE.
Source title: Japanese Journal of Medical Electronics and Biological Engineering
Affiliations: Univ of Tokyo, Inst of Medical, Electronics, Tokyo, Jpn, Univ of Tokyo, Inst of Medical Electronics, Tokyo, Jpn
Authors with affiliations: Tanaka, Hiroshi, Univ of Tokyo, Inst of Medical, Electronics, Tokyo, Jpn, Univ of Tokyo, Inst of Medical Electronics, Tokyo, Jpn; Nakazawa, Shinya, Univ of Tokyo, Inst of Medical, Electronics, Tokyo, Jpn, Univ of Tokyo, Inst of Medical Electronics, Tokyo, Jpn; Akiba, Yuko, Univ of Tokyo, Inst of Medical, Electronics, Tokyo, Jpn, Univ of Tokyo, Inst of Medical Electronics, Tokyo, Jpn; Hirayanagi, Kaname, Univ of Tokyo, Inst of Medical, Electronics, Tokyo, Jpn, Univ of Tokyo, Inst of Medical Electronics, Tokyo, Jpn; Nakamura, Hiroyuki, Univ of Tokyo, Inst of Medical, Electronics, Tokyo, Jpn, Univ of Tokyo, Inst of Medical Electronics, Tokyo, Jpn; Ihara, Tadashi, Univ of Tokyo, Inst of Medical, Electronics, Tokyo, Jpn, Univ of Tokyo, Inst of Medical Electronics, Tokyo, Jpn; Hara, Shoichiro, Univ of Tokyo, Inst of Medical, Electronics, Tokyo, Jpn, Univ of Tokyo, Inst of Medical Electronics, Tokyo, Jpn; Kinoshita, Shigehiro, Univ of Tokyo, Inst of Medical, Electronics, Tokyo, Jpn, Univ of Tokyo, Inst of Medical Electronics, Tokyo, Jpn; Aoki, Takao, Univ of Tokyo, Inst of Medical, Electronics, Tokyo, Jpn, Univ of Tokyo, Inst of Medical Electronics, Tokyo, Jpn; Yamanoi, Noboru, Univ of Tokyo, Inst of Medical, Electronics, Tokyo, Jpn, Univ of Tokyo, Inst of Medical Electronics, Tokyo, Jpn; Furukawa, Toshiyuki, Univ of Tokyo, Inst of Medical, Electronics, Tokyo, Jpn, Univ of Tokyo, Inst of Medical Electronics, Tokyo, Jpn
Abstract: The development of a fluid therapy consultation system which can manage patient hydration and intravenous electrolytes is described. The system has the following features: (1) the system displays inputs and outputs on a CRT, shortening consultation times; (2) The system is able to detect the input errors and gives warnings with comments and instructions. (3) Through the use of a safety zone chart, the user can check consultation results offered by the system; (4) The consultation can be completed in five minutes in most instances.

Authors: Lesmo L., Marzuoli M., Molino G., Torasso P.
Title: An expert system for the evaluation of liver functional assessment
Affiliations: Istituto di Scienze dell'Informazione, Università di Torino, C. so M. D'Azeglio, 42, Torino, 10125, Italy; Clinica Medica B, Università di Torino, Via Genova 3, Torino, 10126, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Lesmo, L., Istituto di Scienze dell'Informazione, Università di Torino, C. so M. D'Azeglio, 42, Torino, 10125, Italy, Clinica Medica B, Università di Torino, Via Genova 3, Torino, 10126, Italy; Marzuoli, M., Istituto di Scienze dell'Informazione, Università di Torino, C. so M. D'Azeglio, 42, Torino, 10125, Italy, Clinica Medica B, Università di Torino, Via Genova 3, Torino, 10126, Italy; Molino, G., Istituto di Scienze dell'Informazione, Università di Torino, C. so M. D'Azeglio, 42, Torino, 10125, Italy, Clinica Medica B, Università di Torino, Via Genova 3, Torino, 10126, Italy; Torasso, P., Istituto di Scienze dell'Informazione, Università di Torino, C. so M. D'Azeglio, 42, Torino, 10125, Italy, Clinica Medica B, Università di Torino, Via Genova 3, Torino, 10126, Italy
Abstract: The paper describes an expert system for the assessment of the liver function. Since the system must act as an intelligent assistant for a general physician, a major emphasis has been laid upon its interactive capabilities. In particular, the user can ask the system how a given conclusion has been reached (explanation facilities) and can alter the normal operation flow. In the design of the system, the different significance and availability of the clinical data and the laboratory tests have been taken into account: The investigations about a given patient start from the clinical data, and only when there is some evidence of hepatopathy are the results of some laboratory tests requested. The final result of the investigations consists of the assessment of the liver function in terms of four aspects (biosynthesis, cholestasis, cytolysis, reactivity), each of which is assigned a linguistic value describing its impairment degree. The techniques adopted in the system are based on Artifical Intelligence methodologies augmented with linguistic terms handled according to the fuzzy set theory. © 1984 Plenum Publishing Corporation.
Index Keywords: computer analysis; diagnosis; human; liver; liver disease; liver function test; organization and management; Diagnosis, Computer-Assisted; Human; Liver Diseases; Support, Non-U.S. Gov't

Title: L'homme machine - Künstliche Menschen in Philosophie, Mechanik und Literatur, betrachtet aus der Sicht der Wissenschaftstheorie
Source title: Journal for General Philosophy of Science - Zeitschrift für Allgemeine Wissenschaftstheorie
Affiliations: Fachbereich 5, Universität Duisburg, Postfach 10 16 29, Duisburg, D-4100, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Tietzel, M., Fachbereich 5, Universität Duisburg, Postfach 10 16 29, Duisburg, D-4100, Germany
Abstract: The idea of man imitating by his own inventions capacities, considered genuinely human, like talking, making music or thinking, has fascinated man's phantasy at all times. The present article analyzes in the light of philosophy of science some of the attempts to tackle this idea in fields as dissimilar as philosophy, mechanics (cybernetics included), and literature, and it tries to lay bare connexions existing and to describe the history of the influence of this idea. The investigation begins with the 17th century mechanistic materialism and it extends to recent research in "artifical intelligence". © 1984 Franz Steiner Verlag Wiesbaden GmbH.

Title: CAD-Directed Inspection
Authors with affiliations: Hopp, T.H.; Hocken, R.J.
Abstract: We describe a control system architecture, based on hierarchical, task-decomposition techniques, for multi-axis coordinate measuring machines. An inspection program consists of a series of high level goals to be satisfied. Goals are satisfied when specified information has been obtained regarding the part. There is a decision hierarchy, each level of which provides logic for partially decomposing goals into simpler goals. The control system executes the inspection program by interpreting the decision hierarchy logic. A world model hierarchy executing in parallel with the task decomposition hierarchy provides information which aids in the decomposition decisions at each level. The world model initially consists of prior knowledge of the part and workstation, and evolves as inspection proceeds, accumulating the results of inspection. The world model allows an inspection task to adapt to the particular part being inspected. Programming consists primarily of identifying tolerances to be verified and providing the relationship between tolerances and the geometry of the part. The latter task can be treated as a data base problem of providing a particular "user view" of the geometry of the part and can in large part be easily automated, although there are important computational geometry issues (path planning, surface fitting, etc.) that remain open. The more difficult problems of identifying top-level goals (i.e., tolerances), selecting the probing and the part setup, and so forth we propose to attack using artifical intelligence techniques. Artifical intelligence techniques will allow the convenient incorporation of quality assurance standards into inspection tasks. We expect that this work will also lead to a deeper understanding of data requirements for computer-aided design representation of parts. © 1984 CIRP.
Index Keywords: DATABASE SYSTEMS - Applications; ARTIFICIAL INTELLIGENCE TECHNIQUES; CONTROL SYSTEM ARCHITECTURE; INSPECTION CONTROL HIERARCHY; MACHINE MOTIONS; MULTI-AXIS COORDINATE MEASURING MACHINES; SERVO COMMANDS; INSPECTION

Title: AUTOMATION IN OUTER SPACE: CREATING HIGH-LEVEL CONTROL STRATEGIES.
Authors with affiliations: Heer, Ewald
Abstract: For future missions in space, engineers must find the most effective location of functions between humans and intelligent machines. Envisioned and planned systems for outer space will require large antennas, service platforms, space stations and manufacturing and processing facilities. Their construction, operation, and maintenance will require technologies not yet in use for similar systems on Earth. The effective allocation of functions between humans and machines in remote operations requires research and developments in artifical intelligence, robotics, tele-operation, man-machine systems, and related problems in human factors. The autonomous machine comprises all the elments of an 'artificial' system, which is located between the human operator and the remote objects and environment.
Index Keywords: SPACE PLATFORMS - Construction; Control facilities

Title: MECHANICAL SOLUTION OF SCHUBERT'S STEAMROLLER BY MANY-SORTED RESOLUTION.
Affiliations: Univ Karlsruhe, Inst fuer, Informatik, Karlsruhe, West Ger, Univ Karlsruhe, Inst fuer Informatik, Karlsruhe, West Ger
Authors with affiliations: Walther, Christoph, Univ Karlsruhe, Inst fuer, Informatik, Karlsruhe, West Ger, Univ Karlsruhe, Inst fuer Informatik, Karlsruhe, West Ger
Abstract: We demonstrate the advantage of using a many-sorted resolution calculus by a mechanical solution of a challenge problem. This problem known as 'Schubert's Steamroller' had been unsolved by automated theorem provers until now. Our solution clearly demonstrates the power of a many-sorted resolution calculus. The proposed method is applicable to all resolution-based inference systems.

Title: An application of computer-aided pattern recognition for audiogram classification
Affiliations: Department of Otolaryngology, Shinshu University, School of Medicine, Matsumoto, Japan
Authors with affiliations: Miyashita, Y., Department of Otolaryngology, Shinshu University, School of Medicine, Matsumoto, Japan; Sakabe, N., Department of Otolaryngology, Shinshu University, School of Medicine, Matsumoto, Japan
Abstract: The authors have developed an automated computer-aided audiogram classification system which executes pattern recognition of the standard pure-tone air-conduction audiogram. The system is composed of a micro-processer, floppy disk drive units, graphic color display and printer. Data of various kinds of audiograms were stored in the floppy disk through the key-board. The micro-computer detected and retrieved the characteristics of plotting curve of hearing loss level at each frequency through artifical intelligence technique. The authors calculated the mean value of hearing level at each frequency of 3000 audiograms, and some characteristics of plotting curve pattern were determined. The audiogram patterns were divided into segments according to these characteristics. By using regression equation technique for each segment, a computer-aided audiogram pattern classification procedure was established. The plotting curve recognition and judgement of hearing level utilizing the computer showed no significant differences from those done by physicians. This new system can be effectively applied in screening audiometry and automated health testing.
Index Keywords: audiometry; auditory system; computer analysis; computer assisted diagnosis; diagnosis; human; pattern recognition

Title: INTELLIGENT SUPERCOMPUTERS: THE JAPANESE COMPUTER SPUTNIK.
Source title: Journal of Information and Image Management
Authors with affiliations: Walter, Gerry
Abstract: Japan's government-supported 'Fifth-Generation Computer Project' has had a pronounced effect on the American computer and information systems industry. The U. S. firms are intensifying their research on the production of intelligent supercomputers, a combination of computer architecture and artificial intelligence software programs. While the present generation of computers is built for the processing of numbers, the new supercomputers will be designed specifically for the solution of symbolic problems and the use of artifical intelligence software. This paper lightly examines one of the many aspects of supercomputer applications. Artificial intelligence, semantic memories (memories organized for informed search), distributed logic networks and many other new terms are now used by systems architects preparing for the future. A reading list of 3 items is suggested.
Index Keywords: COMPUTER ARCHITECTURE - Research; COMPUTER SOFTWARE - Research; SYSTEMS SCIENCE AND CYBERNETICS - Artificial Intelligence; TECHNOLOGICAL FORECASTING - Applications; DISTRIBUTED LOGIC NETWORKS; SEMANTIC MEMORIES; SUPERCOMPUTERS; Computers

Authors: Airenti Gabriella, Bara Bruno G., Colombetti Marco
Title: KNOWLEDGE AND THOUGHT IN A COGNITIVE SYSTEM (1).
Authors with affiliations: Airenti, Gabriella; Bara, Bruno G.; Colombetti, Marco
Abstract: This paper deals with some connections among knowledge, thought and learning in the human mind. The standpoint adopted is that of artifical intelligence (AI). The authors begin from a proposal on the structure of human knowledge whose salient features are: i) the identification of a theory/model dichotomy, ii) the constructive nature of the theory, iii) the organization of reality performed by the model according dealt the theory. Thought processes considered as knowledge manipulating procedures are dealt with, along with the connections among thought, perception and motor skills. The problem of knowledge modification and acquisition is discussed.
Index Keywords: Systems science and cybernetics

Title: PATTERN RECOGNITION STORAGE AND USING QUANTITATIVE SIMILARITY MEASURES.
Affiliations: Memphis State Univ, Dep of, Mathematical Sciences, Memphis, TN,, USA, Memphis State Univ, Dep of Mathematical Sciences, Memphis, TN, USA
Authors with affiliations: Lee, Edward T., Memphis State Univ, Dep of, Mathematical Sciences, Memphis, TN,, USA, Memphis State Univ, Dep of Mathematical Sciences, Memphis, TN, USA
Abstract: One of the important areas in the interaction between pattern recognition and artificial intelligence is the pattern database, and pattern organization, storage, and retrieval. A structural approach using fuzzy languages and similarity measures is applied to pattern recognition, storage, and retrieval. The correspondences between pattern space, tree space and fuzzy languages are presented. Leukocytes, chromosomes, geometric figures, houses, houses with high roof and churches, are illustrative examples of this approach. The results may have useful application in pattern recognition, artificial intelligence, similarity retrieval techniques and pictorial information systems.

Title: Multiple representations of space underlying behavior
Affiliations: Department of Psychology, Hebrew University of Jerusalem, Mount Scopus, Jerusalem, Israel; Department of Computer and Information Science, Center for Systems Neuroscience, University of Massachusetts, Amherst, Mass. 01003, United States
Authors with affiliations: Lieblich, I., Department of Psychology, Hebrew University of Jerusalem, Mount Scopus, Jerusalem, Israel; Arbib, M.A., Department of Computer and Information Science, Center for Systems Neuroscience, University of Massachusetts, Amherst, Mass. 01003, United States
Abstract: We argue that a map is meaningless unless we have a process for using it. Thus, in this paper, we not only offer the world graph as a representation of relationships among situations the animal has encountered and may encounter again, but we also offer algorithms for how the information encoded in the world graph may be used by the animal in determining its behavior. Each node of the graph encodes a recognizable situation in the animal's world, but a given place may well be encoded in a number of different nodes. Nodes not only require algorithms for the recognition of the situation; they store information about drive reduction associated with the encoded situation. We note that the use of graphs as a basis for exploring some search space is well known in artificial intelligence (AI), but we stress the importance of the animal's exploration of its environment for growing the graph, as distinct from the mathematically described potential nodes frequent in AI search spaces. To explore a number of hypotheses about the way information in the world graph is used to guide the animal's movement, we recall a number of classical experiments on maze exploration by animals, and use them to argue for the nonlocal hypothesis (selection of a path does not depend only upon information about the immediate environment of the animal) and the competing nodes hypothesis (more than one drive may enter into the determination of the animal's behavior at any time). An important feature of the model is that it yields exploration and latent learning without the introduction of an exploratory drive. We also note that the performance exhibited by the model appears to be state-dependent when the animal operates under high drive levels. The drive-interaction matrix is offered as a subject for future research. We complement the presentation of the world graph model, its drive dynamics, and how these are constrained by experiments on maze behavior, with a brief analysis of maps in the brain. We distinguish egocentric maps–which we relate to the many visual systems–from allocentric maps. We offer a somewhat unconventional view of short-term and long-term memory. We examine cooperative computation in somatotopically organized networks, relating this to visually guided behavior in the frog, and to the interaction of colliculus and cortex in the control of eye movements. We examine, but do not advocate, the hypothesis that the hippocampus is a cognitive map. We do stress that if it is a cognitive map, it must be seen as a chart of the local neighborhood, rather than the whole atlas; and we note that the cognitive map hypothesis would lead one to expect the region to exhibit activation of place cells before the animal leaves the previous place. © 1982, Cambridge University Press. All rights reserved.
Author Keywords: animal behavior; artifical intelligence; brain theory; cognitive map; drive; hippocampus; maze; motivation; motor control; parietal lobe; spatial representation; vision
Index Keywords: algorithm; animal; behavior; central nervous system; cognition; ecology; environment; hippocampus; motivation; motor control; nonhuman; spatial orientation; theoretical study; vision; visual system

Authors: Matsushima K., Okada N., Sata T.
Title: The Integration of CAD and CAM by Application of Artificial-Intelligence Techniques
Affiliations: University of Tokyo
Authors with affiliations: Matsushima, K., University of Tokyo; Okada, N., University of Tokyo; Sata, T., University of Tokyo
Abstract: This paper reports on the development of a new type of process planning system by application of two artifical-intelligence techniques: "Production system" and "Backtrack search". This system can automatically generate the optimum machining sequence for the finished geometry in the data base given as the out-put from the CAD system. This system uses empirical knowledge about machining stylized into Production Rules, and a separate deductive algorithm. The system is written in PASCAL which permits use of user-defined data structures and recursion. These features bring flexibility, generality, and simplicity to the system. The results are put into an EXAPT part program which is ready for execution. This allows for the integration of COMPAC and EXAPT. © 1982 CIRP.

Title: A logical argument about artificial intelligence
Affiliations: 81 Via Corsica, I-25100 Brescia, Italy
Authors with affiliations: Cotogno, P.G., 81 Via Corsica, I-25100 Brescia, Italy
Abstract: The paper is concerned with the problem of theoretical limits to the abstract capabilities of artifical intelligence.If [AI] is the class of problems solvable by means of Artificial Intelligence, and [HM] is the class of problems the human mind deals with, the ultimate end of the whole field of Artificial Intelligence can be considered to make the two classes co-extensive (Newell-Simon's Thesis). The question is discussed here from the standpoint of formal logic: [AI] is represented by the class of first-order syntactical deductions and [HM] by the class of first-order semantical consequences. The logical system used is the J.A. Robinson's resolution-based logic, which is shortly introduced both as a first-order system and as a programming system. Then the Newell-Simon's Thesis can be replaced by the Hilbert's Thesis - the claim that the significant part of mathematics is captured by formal and finite manipulations on concrete symbols - and studied as a very abstract statement. Eventually a diagonal proposition, constructed within the resolution-based logic, shows that the Hilbert's Thesis is untenable, and the Newell-Simon's Thesis implausible.
Index Keywords: Systems science and cybernetics; artificial intelligence; computer analysis

Title: ZMOB: hardware from a user's viewpoint.
Source title: Pattern recognition and image processing. Proc. IEEE Computer Society conference, Dallas, 1981, (IEEE, New York; CH1595 8)
Affiliations: Artiffical Intell Group, Computer Sci Dept, Univ of Maryland, Coll Park, MD 20742, USA., United States
Authors with affiliations: Rieger, C., Artiffical Intell Group, Computer Sci Dept, Univ of Maryland, Coll Park, MD 20742, USA., United States
Abstract: ZMOB is a large research multiprocessor under construction at Maryland. Based on 256 autonomous microprocessors which are interconnected by a high-speed 48-bit-wide 'conveyor belt' ring, ZMOB will have a 100M instruction per second througput, and a 16M byte memory. It is anticipated that ZMOB will be useful to many areas of computer science, especially artifical intelligence, networking, and image processing. -from Author
Index Keywords: artificial intelligenc; image processing; networking

Title: COMPUTER AIDED DESIGN: AN INTERSECTION OF IDEAS.
Authors with affiliations: Warman, E.A.
Abstract: The design processes analyzed and a general model of the Computer Aided Design process is constructed. Extending this model to incorporate the full requirements of a designer, shows that the incorporation of Artifical Intelligence Methodology into Computer Aided Design is a natural and expected development.
Index Keywords: SYSTEMS SCIENCE AND CYBERNETICS - Artificial Intelligence; Computer aided design
Conference name: Artif Intell and Pattern Recognition in Comput Aided Des, Proc of the IFIP TC-5 Working Conf

Title: A preferential, pattern-seeking, Semantics for natural language inference
Affiliations: Artificial Intelligence Laboratory, Standord University, Stanford, CA 94305, United States
Authors with affiliations: Wilks, Y., Artificial Intelligence Laboratory, Standord University, Stanford, CA 94305, United States
Abstract: The paper describes the way in which a Preference Semantics system for natural language analysis and generation tackles a difficult class of anaphoric inference problems: those requiring either analytic (conceptual) knowledge of a complex sort, or requiring weak inductive knowledge of the course of events in the real world. The method employed converts all available knowledge to a canonical template form and endeavors to create chains of non-reductive inferences from the unknowns to the possible referents. Its method for this is consistent with the overall principle of "semantic preference" used to set up the original meaning representation. © 1975.
Index Keywords: COMPUTER PROGRAMMING LANGUAGES - LISP; SYSTEMS SCIENCE AND CYBERNETICS - Artifical Intelligence; SEMANTICS; INFORMATION SCIENCE
Funding Details: U.S. Department of Defense, DOD: SD 183; Advanced Research Projects Agency, ARPA

Title: On the properties of fuzzy switching functions
Affiliations: Computer Science Department, New Mexico Institute of Mining and Technology, Socorro, NM, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kandel, A., Computer Science Department, New Mexico Institute of Mining and Technology, Socorro, NM, United States
Abstract: A strictly binary approach to the treatment of switching circuits today is not always adequate to describe systems in the real world. This approach is partly due, to the relative simplicity of designing binary switching systems, and to the fact that basic switching modules in common use are two-positional. Consequently, every variable in Boolean logic is assumed to be two-valued. However, because of real-world constraints, the attributes of system variables are often ambiguously defined. In other words, quite often variables might have values other than falsehood and truth. Cases with such attributes arise, for example in artifical intelligence and related subjects. Ever since Zadeh introduced the idea of fuzzy set theory [11 by utilizing the concept of membership grade, a number of authors have been concerned with the analysis and applications of fuzzy models. Especially, the relation of fuzzy to switching systems have been discussed in [2]—[12] and by other researchers in relation to other topics. In this paper we are concerned with the study of fuzzy switching functions and their properties. Special attention is devoted to their minimization, enumeration, and their application to Boolean static hazard detection. © 1975 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Decision theory and artificial intelligence: I. A semantics-based region analyzer
Affiliations: Computer Science Department, Artificial Intelligence Laboratory, Stanford University, Stanford, CA 94305, United States; Jet Propulsion Laboratory, 4800 Oakgrove Drive, Pasadena, CA 91103, United States
Authors with affiliations: Feldman, J.A., Computer Science Department, Artificial Intelligence Laboratory, Stanford University, Stanford, CA 94305, United States; Yakimovsky, Y., Jet Propulsion Laboratory, 4800 Oakgrove Drive, Pasadena, CA 91103, United States
Abstract: Mathematical decision theory can be combined with heuristic techniques to attack Artificial Intelligence problems. As a first example, the problem of breaking an image into meaningful regions is considered. Bayesian decision theory is seen to provide a mechanism for including problem dependent (semantic) information in a general system. Some results are presented which make the computation feasible. A programming system based on these ideas and its application to road scenes is described. © 1974.
Index Keywords: BIOMEDICAL ENGINEERING - Cardiology; COMPUTER PROGRAMMING; DECISION THEORY AND ANALYSIS; SYSTEMS SCIENCE AND CYBERNETICS - Artifical Intelligence; PATTERN RECOGNITION SYSTEMS
Funding Details: National Science Foundation, NSF

Title: Some Recent Work in Artificial Intelligence
Affiliations: Rockford Research Institute, Cambridge, Mass., United States
Authors with affiliations: Solomonoff, R.J., Rockford Research Institute, Cambridge, Mass., United States
Abstract: This paper will review certain approaches to artifical intelligence research-mainly work done since 1960. An important area of research involves designing a machine that can adequately improve its own performance as well as solve other problems normally requiring human intelligence. Work in heuristic programming that seems most relevant to this goal will be discussed at length. Important subproblems are devising techniques for self-improvement, the general problem of deciding what task to best work on next in a network of tasks, and the general problem of how to mechanize learning or inductive inference. Some work in linguistics and pattern recognition is directly concerned with the induction problem. Another area of research that will be treated is simulation of organic evolution. © 1966, IEEE. All rights reserved.
